The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Jehovah is his proper name of his owne ImpoÅ¿ition,Iehovah. and incommunicable to any Creature, of what Rank or Quality Å¿oever: a Name of Å¿uch immoderate Reverence amongÅ¿t the oldeÅ¿t Jewes, that it was forbidden to be written right or pronounced at all in this world, but by the High PrieÅ¿t, and but in

And as it would Å¿eem to be by the Jewes, our Saviour might not himÅ¿elfe make uÅ¿e of this Name in kinde: for after their malicious rate of Tradition, they hold that he did all his miracles by the ParaphraÅ¿ticall Tetragrammaton, or Shem hamphoraÅ¿h (as they call this Name at length and in other words) and this way of Enunciation they Å¿ay was cut into his feet, and produced as occaÅ¿ion Å¿erved, as to caÅ¿t out Devills (by a knowne ReceÅ¿Å¿e of the blacke Art) through him that is the Prince. div.head: CHAP. VII. The Aera of the Olympiads.
div.p: THe Olympick Games were inÅ¿tituted for the exerciÅ¿e of the Grecian Youth, by Hercules (as the Tradition go's) to the honor of Jupiter Olympius, near unto whoÅ¿e Temple they were perform'd in the Olympian field. If therefore 90 Olympiads bee multiplied by 4, they make up 360 Julian years, to which alÅ¿o muÅ¿t bee added the three firÅ¿t years of the 91 Olympiad, and then they are 363, which added to 445, make up 808 years before the PaÅ¿Å¿ion of our Saviour, which falleth with the 3173 year of the World, and is the Aera of the Olympiads.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Aera Æ²rbis Conditae.
div.p:
THe Italians, by an old cuÅ¿tom, uÅ¿ed to account their years from the time of their firÅ¿t Plantation; yet in this the leÅ¿Å¿er towns were more happie then the Mother Citie: Rome her Å¿elf not having attein'd to know her own begining, til Cato's time; who conÅ¿idering the abÅ¿urditie, Å¿earched the CenÅ¿or's Tables, and bringing down the account to the firÅ¿t ConÅ¿uls, got within a little of Æ²rbs Condita. q.l: Æ²rbi feÅ¿tus erat, dixere Palilia, Patres
Hic primus coepit moenibus eÅ¿Å¿e dies.

div.p: The Interval, as Cato found it, amounted to 243 years, Terence Varro (who at the Å¿ame time Å¿tudied the point) reckoned one year more; and from thence, Å¿aith Scaliger, in factiones duas res diÅ¿ceÅ¿Å¿it, there became two Å¿ides, one for the Catonian Palilia, the other for the Varronian; though Petavius (that Scaligero-maÅ¿tix) affirmeth that the former was not Cato's opinion; and Sethus CalviÅ¿ius demonÅ¿trateth that they were both but one.

This EpilogiÅ¿m was found out by Tarutius (or as hee is more rightly called (Taruntius Firmanus, a great AÅ¿trologer of thoÅ¿e daies, who at the Å¿olicitation of Varro caÅ¿t the Nativitie of Rome; which to recover, hee firÅ¿t of all tried for the Founders HoroÅ¿cope. To attain to this, hee entred into a conÅ¿ideration of the main actions of his life; and becauÅ¿ hee had underÅ¿tood by Tradition that there hapned an EclipÅ¿ when Romulus was conceived in the womb, hee went the Hermetical waie, as that is called, to finde out the Nativitie by the conception.
After conÅ¿ultation with the Stars, and a due compariÅ¿on of this with what was otherwiÅ¿e known, ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , hee confidently pronounced this Judgment.
That Romulus was conceived in the firÅ¿t year of the Å¿econdPlutar. in Roma.

Olympiad, the 23 daie of the (Egyptian) moneth Choeac, at the third hour of the daie, the Sun beeing then totally EclipÅ¿ed. That hee was born the one and twentieth of the Moneth Thoth, about the Sun riÅ¿ing. That the Foundation of Rome was laied the ninth daie of Pharmuth between two and three a clock in the morning, the Moon beeing then in Jugo. So the AÅ¿trologer.

OtherwiÅ¿e the Tradition was (which alÅ¿o Taruns conÅ¿idered) that the Foundation of Rome was laid in the third year of the Å¿ixth Olympiad, the Sun and Moon then beeing
in an Ecliptical conjunction, which defection was noted by Antimachus the TeÃ¯an Poet.

For the firÅ¿t EclipÅ¿, as his Tables (which are Å¿aid to bee thoÅ¿e of Hipparchus) directed him, it fell out in the firÅ¿t year of the Å¿econd Olympiad, upon the 23 daie of the Moneth Choeac, which anÅ¿wereth to the 24 of June at three a clock in the morning. Yet according to Tyche, Ptolomie's, and the King AlphonÅ¿us their Tables, the latitude was then Å¿o great that there could bee no EclipÅ¿ at that time. So Sethus CalviÅ¿ius and others. Nicolas Muller pretended, that this EclipÅ¿ could not bee found out by the Prutenick Tables, but by the FriÅ¿ian, which hee was then about (his own and more elaborate) hee promiÅ¿eth to account for it. CalviÅ¿ius anÅ¿wereth, that the Prutenick Tables according to Copernicus his HypotheÅ¿es were moÅ¿t exactly performed, and that hee doubted Muller could not Å¿tand to his word. Yet Å¿ince that Muller hath calculated this EclipÅ¿, and found it to bee by his FriÅ¿ian Tables, according as the AÅ¿trologer Å¿et down.

Henrie Bunting findeth it in the Å¿econd year of the Å¿econd Olympiad, one year later then the AÅ¿trologer. And this may Å¿eem to bee nothing out of the waie. For DionyÅ¿ius HalicarnaÅ¿sius reporteth, that Romulus as hee came not into the world, Å¿o hee went not out without an EclipÅ¿. Now Romulus reigned 37 years, at which verie time the Sun was EclipÅ¿ed, upon Saturdaie the 26 of Maie about 7 of the clock in the afternoonâª the Sun then Å¿etting at Rome; and the greateÅ¿t abÅ¿urditie CalviÅ¿ius could finde in this was, that it Å¿etteth off but 18 years for the age of Romulus at the building of Rome; which as hee think's could not make him mature enough for the importance of this undertaking; but conÅ¿idering all other circumÅ¿tances agree Å¿o well, the Acception is unjuÅ¿t enough.

For the other EclipÅ¿ pretended to bee at the Foundation of the Citie. Nicolas Muller findeth that alÅ¿o in his FriÅ¿ian tables, yet confeÅ¿Å¿eth it could not bee Å¿een at Rome; but in AÅ¿ia 'twas viÅ¿ible hee Å¿aith, and Å¿o might bee known to Antimachus.

And this maketh Å¿omthing for the AÅ¿trologer, who (as Cicero citeth him) found the Moon at the Foundation in
Jugo, that is, as Solin may Å¿eem to interpret it, in Libra; the rather, becauÅ¿ the PoÃ«t Manilius Å¿aith, that Rome was built in Libra. So Petavius: but Solinus (though hee knew not what hee Å¿aid) yet Å¿aith too, That the Sun was then in Taurus, which is demonÅ¿trated by Bunting, and moreover, that it was in the twentieth degree; and therefore the more learned Scaliger and his CalviÅ¿ius interpret the AÅ¿trologers in Jugo, to bee the Å¿ame which is now Å¿aid in Nodo, which is as much as to Å¿ay, that the Sun and Moon were then in Conjunction, as Muller Å¿aith well, and that the Sun was intra terminos Eclipticos, within the Ecliptick terms at Rome, but not Å¿o far as to make the defection viÅ¿ible in that Horizon.

HowÅ¿oever the AÅ¿trologer according to his Calculation Å¿et down that Rome was built in the third year of the Å¿ixth Olympiad, which Terence Varro took for his reÅ¿olution; and Å¿o reckoned from the Regifugium to the Palilia 244 years; Marcus Cicero, Titus Pomponius Atticus and the Emperor AuguÅ¿tus approving the EpilogiÅ¿ms, and beÅ¿ides them Plutarch, Plinie, Paterculus and others, and 'twas the received opinion; and is infallibly demonÅ¿trated in Mercator's Chronologie, by eight Å¿everal celeÅ¿tial Characters or EclipÅ¿es, which calculated to NabonaÅ¿Å¿ar's Aera fall even with the AÅ¿trologer. To Å¿ay nothing of CruÅ¿ius, who hath don Å¿omthing to the Å¿ame purpoÅ¿e, or Peter Appian, who evinceth the Å¿ame (I Å¿aie not how truely) out of the Figure of the Heavens, which Turnus found (but as Julius Solinus deÅ¿cribeth it) at the laying of the Foundation, Verrius Flaccus in the FaÅ¿ti Capitolini Å¿etteth down Rome built in the fourth year of the Å¿ixth Olympiad, one year later; and the Canons of EratoÅ¿thenes in the firÅ¿t year of the Å¿eventh Olympiad one year more, or rather but one in all; for the RegiÅ¿ters of the Capitol agree with Cato, and hee differeth nothing from Varro, if CalviÅ¿ius may bee Judge.

Therefore altogether neglecting Temporarius his moroÅ¿iÅ¿itie (who was Å¿o far out of conceit with Turnus, that hee would not believe that there was ever Å¿uch a man as Romulus) we Å¿ay that Rome was founded in the third year of the
Å¿ixth Olympiad which was in the year of the Worlds CreÃ¤tion 3198, and before the Incarnation 750.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Aera Septimanarum Septuaginta, the Å¿eventie Weeks.
div.p: THis Aera was fixed by the Angel Gabriel, Dan. 9. Seventie Weeks (Å¿aith hee to the Prophet) are determined upon the People, &c. verÅ¿ 24. Know therefore and underÅ¿tand, that from the going forth of the Commandment, to restore and build JeruÅ¿alem unto the MeÅ¿Å¿iah the Prince, Å¿hall bee Å¿even Weeks, and threeÅ¿core and two Weeks, &c. And after threeÅ¿core and two Weeks Å¿hall MeÅ¿Å¿iah bee cut off, but not for himÅ¿elf; and the people of the Prince that Å¿hall com Å¿hall deÅ¿troy the Citie and the Sanctuarie, &c. And hee Å¿hall confirm the Covenant with manie for one Week, and in the midÅ¿t of the Week hee Å¿hall cauÅ¿ the Sacrifice and the Oblation to ceaÅ¿, and for the overÅ¿preading of abominations hee Å¿hall make it deÅ¿olate, even until the conÅ¿ummation, &c. The Weeks are to bee underÅ¿tood not of daies, but Years; and thoÅ¿e not of the Moon, but the Sun; and Å¿o 70 by 7 is 490 years, from the time of the going forth of the Commandment &c. unto the Abomination of deÅ¿olation. But where to begin or end this EpilogiÅ¿m, is the vexata QuaeÅ¿tio, as Scaliger cal's it, a queÅ¿tion that hath endured the greateÅ¿t controverÅ¿ie, involved with circumÅ¿tances of Å¿uch notable intricacie, that a Scholar of verie great parts ('tis reported by one that knew the man) fell mad with Å¿tudying how to make this good.

Som reckon the EpilogiÅ¿m from Cyrus, others from Darius HyÅ¿taÅ¿pis, and Å¿om from the Å¿eventh, others from the 20 of Artaxerxes Longimanus, accordingly ending the Weeks, Å¿om at the profanation of the Temple by Antiochus, others at the deÅ¿truction of the Temple by Pompey, or that of Herod, or elÅ¿ at the PaÅ¿Å¿ion.

The trueÅ¿t of the falÅ¿, is that which begineth at the Å¿eventh year of Artaxerxes Longimanus, and endeth in our Saviours
PaÅ¿Å¿ion: for this maketh a good account of the years. It was the opinion of the learned Bunting, Funccius, &c. but that which I perceiv to bee reÅ¿ted upon, is the judgment of Scaliger followed by CalviÅ¿ius, and this begineth the EpilogiÅ¿m at the Å¿econd year of Darius Nothus, and determineth it in the final deÅ¿truction of JeruÅ¿alem by Titus. For the Angel Å¿aith expreÅ¿ly, that after Å¿even Weeks and Å¿ixtie two weeks, the MeÅ¿Å¿iah beeing cut off, the holie Citie Å¿hall bee deÅ¿troied &c. and that in the middle of the Å¿eventieth week the Sacrifice and Oblation Å¿hall ceaÅ¿, and for an overÅ¿preading of abomination, &c. which is plainly called by our Saviour, the abomination of deÅ¿olation, Å¿poken of by Daniel the Prophet &c. and therefore no queÅ¿tion, but the feventie Weeks are to end with the Holie Citie. And this, though Å¿uch an one was given firÅ¿t by Cyrus, and thirdly by Artaxerxes, yet moÅ¿t purpoÅ¿ely from Darius Nothus in the Å¿econd year of his reign. The 13 year of Darius Nothus is the 20 of the PeloponeÅ¿iack war by Thucydides that was the 92 Olympiad, and this was the 3538 from the Worlds CreÃ¤tion, or 4302 of the Julian Period, therefore the 2 year of Darius Nothus was the 4290 of the Julian Period, and that was the 3562 from the worlds CreÃ¤tion. div.head: CHAP. X. Aera Alexandrea,
div.p:
WHat time Seleucus began to Å¿ucceed in his part of the Empire of AÅ¿ia, The Greeks diÅ¿uÅ¿ing their Olympian account, Å¿et up a new Aera, which though it reckoned from the reign of Seleucus, yet it bare the name of the conquerour

Seleucus began to raign twelv years after the death of Alexander, as appeareth by Albategnius and the AlmageÅ¿t; which conÅ¿enteth alÅ¿o to Diodorus Siculus, who affirmeth that the firÅ¿t year of Seleucus was the firÅ¿t of the 117 Olympiad.

Therefore this Aera was fixed in the 4402 of the Julian Period, which was the 3638 from the world's CreÃ¤tion; the Cycle of the Sun was 6, and the Moon 13. The Aera was fixed Å¿aith Scaliger (though Petavius will not yield it) by Calipus of Cyzicum, who finding that Meton's ciclus decennovenalis exceeded the Moon's Revolution one quadrant of a daie, put four of theÅ¿e together, and detracting from thence one whole daie for the quadruple exceÅ¿s of hours, gave an exacter account of the Lunations then before.

And this was in the year of the world 3619 as the EclipÅ¿ aÅ¿Å¿ureth which hap'ned eleven daies before, but becauÅ¿ this fell out to bee in the Å¿econd year of that Olympiad, Calippus altered his minde, and Å¿tayed nineteen years to make his Period concur; but Alexander deceaÅ¿ing within Å¿even years, the Aera could not begin till twelv years after, which was the firÅ¿t of the reign of Seleucus, and 3638 of the World.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Aera Dhilcarnian
div.p:
IS the Å¿ame with the Alexandrea Graecorum, and hath nothing proper but the Name, which it Å¿elf alÅ¿o is nothing but Alexander in other words as by the Arabick Geographer and otherwiÅ¿e 'tis made known. Dhilcarnain, that is, habentis duo cornua, as Albumazer's TranÅ¿lator expreÅ¿Å¿eth it. So Alexander was called with relation to the Ram in Daniel's
ViÅ¿ion as Å¿om divine, but then they are fain to read it Ailcarnain, not conÅ¿idering that it is not the word in Arabick as in Hebrew, for a Ram, the Arabians if they had meant thus, would have Å¿aid not Aiie, but Hamelcarnain; but let that paÅ¿s, for the word written in it's own language manifeÅ¿tly importeth no more then one that hath two horns.

So Alexander, Å¿aith ChriÅ¿tman, might bee called either for that his Empire was bipartite into AÅ¿ia and Syria, (which is not altogether Å¿o true) or otherwiÅ¿e, for that hee joined the EaÅ¿t and WeÅ¿t together with ConqueÅ¿ts, holding as it were the two Hornes of the World in his Victorious hands.

But why Alezander Å¿hould bee called Dhilcarnain or habens duo cornua, Scaliger's reaÅ¿on is beyond exception, and which Petavius himÅ¿elf could not chooÅ¿ but commend. Alexander to raiÅ¿ himÅ¿elf a reputation of Divinitie, Å¿uborned the PrieÅ¿t to entitle him the Å¿on of Corniger Ammon, thenceforth the Cyrenians, who had formerly uÅ¿ed to expreÅ¿s this Jupiter horned in their Coins, transferred this honor to the Conqueror, and Å¿o the reputed Å¿on, as the Father was known by the name of Corniger which when it came to the Arabians was to bee Å¿aid as here it is Dilcarnian.

div.head: CHAP. XII. The Jews Aera.
div.p: ALexander the Great with his Grecian Armie marching towards JeruÅ¿alem with all intention of hoÅ¿tilitie, the High PrieÅ¿ts and Levites came forth to meet him, all in their Holie Garments. The King beholding this reverent AÅ¿Å¿emblie, made an approch himÅ¿elf alone, and drawing near to the High PrieÅ¿t fell down and worÅ¿hipped. The Captains wondring to Å¿ee the Å¿on of Jupiter Ammon, who had given command that all men Å¿hould worÅ¿hip him, himÅ¿elf to fall down to a Jew, Parmenion drew near and made bold to ask him the queÅ¿tion. To whom Alexander; 'Tis not the PrieÅ¿t Å¿aith hee, but his God whom I adore, and who in his verie habit appeared unto mee long ago at Dius in Macedonia, and encouraged mee in my undertakings for the Empire of AÅ¿ia. This don, the King aÅ¿cended the Temple, where Sacrifice firÅ¿t don to God, the prophecie of Daniel was brought forth, the high PrieÅ¿t turning to that place which foretelleth of a mightie Prince of Graecia that was to conquer the PerÅ¿ians, which, the circumÅ¿tances well agreeing, the King readily applyed unto himÅ¿elf, and Å¿o departed verie well pleaÅ¿ed, and full of hope, leaving the People to their Antient peace.Antiquitat. Lib. 11. So their HiÅ¿torian JoÅ¿ephus; and the Book Taanith Cap. 9.

But it is added moreover by Abraham the Levite in his Cabala, that the High PrieÅ¿t by waie of acknowledgment made faith to the King, that all the children which Å¿hould bee born that year to the holie Tribe Å¿hould bee called by his Name; and moreover that from the Å¿ame Time they would henceforth compute their Minian Staros, or Aera of Contracts, &c. fol. 3.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Aera DionyÅ¿iana Philadelphi.
div.p: A CeleÅ¿tial year is Å¿uch an one as kÃ©epeth touch with the Sun, the Months whereof begin at his entrance into the Signs preciÅ¿ely, and eÅ¿pecially Å¿erving for the PrognoÅ¿tication of the SeaÅ¿ons. div.p: JÆ²lius CaeÅ¿ar in the fourth of his DictatorÅ¿hip, appointed his Mathematicians to the Correction of the Roman Year;Dion lib. 11. which is the begining of the Julian Account. div.head: CHAP. XV. Aera Actiacae Victoriae. &c.
div.p:
CAEÅ¿ar AuguÅ¿tus having triumphed over Antonie and Cleopatra in the battel of Actium,
ã in non-Latin alphabet ã Å¿aith Dion, became himÅ¿elf to bee Monarch of the World, ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , &c. inÅ¿omuch that hee gave command that the Empire Å¿hould begin to compute their Acts from this daie's Achievment; which was the Å¿econd of September by Dion. ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , and in the 81 year of DiocleÅ¿ian, and 1112 of NabonaÅ¿Å¿ar. AÅ¿hyr the 29, and 6 of Phamenoth, and this EclipÅ¿, exacted to the Julian form, hapned November 25, a little after midnight, in the year of the World 4313, and 364 from the Incarnation; the Sun was in the 5 of Sagittarie. Therefore as it is called Aera Martyrum, it referreth not to the perÅ¿ecution in the 19 of DiocleÅ¿ian, but to that of his firÅ¿t year,

This Aera is uÅ¿ed by S. AmbroÅ¿e, Epiphanius, Evagrius, Hermannus, Contractus, Bede and others. div.head: CHAP. XVI. Aera ChriÅ¿ti Nati.

div.head: CHAP. XX. What is Proleptical, and what HiÅ¿torical Time.
div.p: HIÅ¿torical Time is that which is deduced from the Aera Orbis Conditi. The firÅ¿t example of Proleptical Time was given by the Greek Church, who in their Computations follow the Holie Scripture of the Septuagint. Therefore their Aera Orbis Conditi is Å¿ixed in 5500 year Ante ChriÅ¿tum Natum. Their more Artificial men, perceiving that this vaÅ¿t EpilogiÅ¿m was good for Å¿omwhat elÅ¿, beÅ¿ides the meaÅ¿uring of Times, applied it to the Characters, and they found that divided by 19 and 28, it gave the Circle of the Sun and Moon, but divided by 15 it gave not the true Indiction; therefore they added 8 to the Å¿umm, and Å¿o it became a Technical or Artificial Period, comprehending the three Characters, and becauÅ¿ it Å¿uppoÅ¿ed 8 years of the Tohu, it was Proleptical; but which the Times following not conÅ¿idering reckoned HiÅ¿torically, as if the Aera Orbis had then been fixed; but are thus to bee corrected.

This Account is uÅ¿ed by the Maronites, Grecians, and generally by the EaÅ¿tern Church, it is called Aera Graecorum, or more properly Periodus ConÅ¿tantinopolitana, from the Seat of the Empire, where it may Å¿eem to have been deviÅ¿ed.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. ConÅ¿idering the CauÅ¿Å¿es of that infinite Varietie which is found to bee amongÅ¿t Chronologers.
div.p: FRederick HuÅ¿man in his EpiÅ¿tle to the Elector Palatine reckoneth up 40 Å¿everal Opinions concerning the Connection of thoÅ¿e two famous Aera's; this of Christi Nati, and that other of Orbis Conditi. And I doubt not but this diverÅ¿itie might bee redoubled if anie bodie would undertake that Å¿uch frivolous pains.

The extremeÅ¿t varietie is that of the Greek and Hebrew Scripture, making a difference of two thouÅ¿and years; an occaÅ¿ion juÅ¿tly taken by Å¿om equally to diÅ¿parage the autoritie either of the one or the other. For it cannot bee but that this EpilogiÅ¿m muÅ¿t bee detracted from the Hebrew, or Å¿uperadded to the Greek, there beeing no mean waie of reconciliation. But certainly, the Hebrew (though I hold it not Å¿o everie waies incorrupt, as if not one jot or title of the Å¿ame Å¿uffered the common fate of time) yet I believ it to bee the Original, and by the incredible diligence of the MaÅ¿ora, Å¿ubÅ¿ervient to the greater providence of God, to retain more of it's own puritie, then anie other Scripture whatÅ¿oever; and therefore that it reÅ¿teth in the Greek TranÅ¿lation, to account for this difference: yet neither do I think that choice AÅ¿Å¿emblie Å¿o neglected by God in a matter Å¿o importantly cared for by him, as to recede Å¿o fouly from their Original.

I rather caÅ¿t this corruption upon the dregs of Time, aÅ¿Å¿uring my Å¿elf that this impoÅ¿ture was put upon us by the HelleniÅ¿ts, thoÅ¿e among them who affected that antient HereÅ¿ie of the ChiliaÅ¿ts; the conceit whereof I affirm to bee the occaÅ¿ion of this corruption.
Other differences in that Connexion have theÅ¿e leÅ¿Å¿er CauÅ¿Å¿es.
That profane HiÅ¿torie maketh no certain account of Time before the Olympiads.

That in the Romane affairs (a moÅ¿t important piece of HiÅ¿torie) the ConÅ¿ulÅ¿hips are not regiÅ¿tred in the FaÅ¿ti with that diÅ¿tinction and care as was neceÅ¿Å¿arie, experience whereof hath been made by the induÅ¿trious examinations of Onuphrius and CuÅ¿pinian.

That Å¿om of them took libertie to relate thoÅ¿e things incluÅ¿ively, which others related excluÅ¿ively.

That Å¿everal Nations reckoned not by the Å¿ame form of years. That all Nations not ChriÅ¿tian, affected an Opinion of greater Antiquitie then their own beginings, endevouring therefore to leav the Storie of their riÅ¿ing as poÅ¿Å¿ibly uncertain to poÅ¿teritie, as in them laie. But the greateÅ¿t cauÅ¿ of all is for that ProfeÅ¿Å¿ed Chronologers of our own times, Å¿uch as Funccius, Beroaldus, Bucholcer, nay Satian, Baronius, Torniellus, and Gordon themÅ¿elvs were altogether unacquainted with anie Artificial waie of this work, not knowing how to make application of Natural and Civil Characters to the aÅ¿Å¿uring of Times. One of the firÅ¿t who began to know what was to bee don in this matter, was the moÅ¿t learned, and perceiving Mercator, who InÅ¿tituted a Chronologie by waie of DemonÅ¿tration AÅ¿tronomical. To this begining, Å¿omthing by Crentzeim was added; but verie much more by Bunting the Autor of a moÅ¿t elaborate Chronologie, demonÅ¿trating by the Characters
of EclipÅ¿es, the Sun and Moons Circles, and with Calculation of everie EclipÅ¿ Å¿ince the world began.

div.head: Of the Meridian without the Globe.
div.p: THe BraÅ¿s Meridian is divided into 4 equal Parts or Quadrants, and each of them Å¿ubdivided into 90 Degrees, that is 360 for the whole Circle. The reaÅ¿on why this Circle is not divided into 360 Degrees throughout, but Å¿till Å¿topping at the 90th, and then again begining 10, 20, 30, &c. is, becauÅ¿ the UÅ¿es of this Meridian, Å¿o far as in Degrees they are concern'd, require not above that Number. As for an Example: One uÅ¿e of the Meridian is to Å¿hew the Elevation of the Pole, but the Pole cannot bee elevated above 90 Degrees. Another is to Å¿hew the Latitude or DiÅ¿tance of a Place from the Equator, which alÅ¿o can never exceed the 4th part of the Circle; for no Place can bee further diÅ¿tant from the Equator then the Pole, which is juÅ¿t that Number of 90 Degrees.

Upon one of the North Quadrants of this Meridian, of Å¿om Great Globes, the Climes are Å¿et to the Å¿everal Degrees of Latitude; and the Length of the longeÅ¿t Daie under the Å¿everal Climes: which (if the Geographers would think Å¿o) might very fitly bee placed on the LeÅ¿Å¿er Globe's; for it were but dividing a Quadrant of the wrong Å¿ide of the Meridian into 90 Degrees, and there would be room enough. But the DiviÅ¿ion upon a Quadrant of the Meridian, is much more artificial, as hereafter Å¿hall bee underÅ¿tood. And the reaÅ¿on why a North Quadrant onely need to bee divided, is, becauÅ¿ for the Climes of the Southern Latitude the reaÅ¿on is the Å¿ame. Upon the North End, a Å¿mall Circle of BraÅ¿s is Å¿et, and divided into two equal parts, and each of them into twelv, that is, twentie four in all. This Circle is the onelie one above the Globe, which is not imagined upon the Earth, but is there placed to Å¿hew the hour of the daie and night, in anie place where the Daie and night exceed not 24 hours: therefore it is called Cyclus Horarius. And to this purpoÅ¿e there is Å¿et down upon the Å¿ame Horizon a Calendar, and that of three Å¿orts in Å¿om Globes: Of two in the moÅ¿t, the one whereof is called the Julian, or Old, the other the Gregorian, or New Accompt, reckoning this latter 10 daies before the former, and the third Å¿ort, where it is found, thirteen. Now though it bee true that the greateÅ¿t part of that which is written upon the Horizon, more nearly concerneth the CeleÅ¿tial then the TerreÅ¿trial Globe; yet it is not altogether unuÅ¿eful here: and eÅ¿pecially it will bee nothing out of the Geographer's way to take along with him the ground of Difference in the 3, principally in the 2 Å¿orts of Calendars.

div.head: The ReaÅ¿on of the Difference in Computation betwixt the Old and New Accompts.
div.p: A Year is that Å¿pace of time in which the Sun goeth through the whole Circle of the Zodiack, as from the Tropick of Cancer, to the Tropick of Capricorn, and Å¿o to the Tropick of Cancer again, or from the Equinoctial to the Equinoctial, or from anie other Point of the Zodiack to the Å¿ame again. Now, becauÅ¿ of the unequal Motion of the Sun (depending upon reaÅ¿ons deeply engaged in the Theorical Part of the Spheer, and therefore here to bee taken upon truÅ¿t) it ever was, and yet is, a very hard matter to determine exactly in what Å¿pace of time this Revolution of the Sun in the Zodiack is made; inÅ¿omuch that one Å¿aid, CenÅ¿orinus de Die Natali. that the Year conÅ¿iÅ¿ted of Å¿o manie daies, and how much more or leÅ¿s no bodie knoweth.

This uncertaintie brought Å¿o much confuÅ¿ion upon the Old Romane Calendars, that Time with them was grown a Commoditie, and bought and Å¿old at a price. Their PrieÅ¿ts, who had to do with this Affair, having in their power to make anie year longer or Å¿horter at their pleaÅ¿ure; which the Emperor Julius CaeÅ¿ar looking upon as a matter no waie below his greateÅ¿t conÅ¿ideration, adviÅ¿ed with Å¿om Egyptian Mathematicians about it, by whoÅ¿e InÅ¿tructions hee found that the Sun's yearlie Motion in the Zodiack, was performed in the Å¿pace of 365 daies, and one 4th part of a daie, or 6 hours.

The 6 odd hours hee cauÅ¿Å¿ed to bee reÅ¿erved in Å¿tore till everie fourth year, that is, till they made 24 hours, or one whole daie; Å¿o accounting, that the 3 firÅ¿t years Å¿hould conÅ¿iÅ¿t of 365 daies, and the fourth of 366, one daie more; and everie fourth year was therefore (as Å¿till it is) called the Leap Year, and the thing it Å¿elf Intercalation, or putting in betwixt the Calendar.

'Twas verie much that the Emperor did, and hee left as much to do; for though it cannot yet bee found out exactly
in what Å¿pace of the time the Sun goeth his yearlie courÅ¿, yet thus much is made good by infallible experience that the Emperor's Mathematicians allotted too much for the Number of daies: they were in the right, for it it is certain no year can conÅ¿iÅ¿t of more then 365, but for the odd hours it is as certain that they cannot bee fewer then five, nor Å¿o manie as 6; Å¿o that the doubt is upon the Minutes, 60 whereof go to the making up of an Hour; a Å¿mall matter one would think, and yet how great in the receÅ¿s and conÅ¿equence wee Å¿hall Å¿ee.

Julius CaeÅ¿ar allotted 365 daies and 6 hours to this Revolution, but the Sun goeth about in leÅ¿s time, that is, (according to the moÅ¿t exact Accompt) in 365 daies, 5 hours, 49 Minutes, and a little more; Å¿o that the Emperor's year is much about 10 Minutes greater then the Sun's, which muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿itie breed a difference of Å¿o manie Minutes everie year, betwixt the Year, which the Sun it Å¿elf deÅ¿cribe's in the Zodiack; and That, which is reckoned upon in the Calendar, which though for a year or two may paÅ¿s inÅ¿enÅ¿ibly, yet in the Å¿pace of 134 years it will riÅ¿e to an whole daie, that is the Begining of the year in the Calendar muÅ¿t bee Å¿et one daie back. As for Example: Let the year begin at the Vernal Equinox or Spring: In the Emperor's time that fell out to bee at the 24th of March, but now this year it fell out upon the 10th of March, 13 daies backwards, and Å¿omwhat more, and Å¿o if it bee let alone will go back to the 1 of March, and 1 of Februarie, till EaÅ¿ter com to bee on ChriÅ¿tmas Daie, and Å¿o infinitely.

To reform this difference in the Accompt, Å¿om of the later Romane BiÅ¿hops earneÅ¿tly endeavoured. And the thing was brought to that perfection it now Å¿tandeth in (Å¿o much as it is) by Gregorie the 13th, in the Year 1582. His Mathematicians (whereof Lilius was the chief) adviÅ¿ed him thus: That conÅ¿idering there had been an Agitation in the Councel of Nice Å¿omwhat concerned in this matter upon the motion of that QueÅ¿tion about the Celebration of EaÅ¿ter: And that the Fathers of that AÅ¿Å¿emblie after due deliberation with the AÅ¿tronomers of that time, had fixed the Vernal
Equinox at the 21 of March, and conÅ¿idering alÅ¿o that Å¿ince that time a difference of 10 whole daies had been paÅ¿t over in the Calendar, that is, that the Vernal Equinox or Spring; which began upon the 21 of March, had prevented Å¿o much as to begin in Gregorie's daies at the 10th of the Å¿ame, 10 daies difference or thereabouts; they adviÅ¿ed that 10 daies Å¿hould bee cut off from the Calendar, which was don, and the 10 daies taken out of October of that Year 1582, as being the Moneth of that Year in which that Pope was born; Å¿o that when they came to the 5 of the Moneth, they reckoned the 15, and Å¿o the Equinox was com up to it's place again, and hapned upon the 21 of March, as at the Councel of Nice. But that Lilius Å¿hould bring back the Begining of the Year to the Times of the Nicen Councel, and no further, is to be marvelled at. Hee Å¿hould have brought it back to the Emperor's own time, where the miÅ¿take was firÅ¿t entered, and, inÅ¿tead of 10, cut of 13 daies; however this is the ReaÅ¿on why theÅ¿e 2 Calendars, written upon the Horizon, differ the Å¿pace of 10 daies one from the other. And as the Old Accompt was called the Julian, from the Emperor; Å¿o the New is called from Gregorie the Pope and Lilius the chief Agent, the Gregorian or Lilian Accompt: and the Julian is termed the Old Style, the Gregorian the New, as in the converÅ¿ation of Letters betwixt Us and ThoÅ¿e on the other Å¿ide of the Seas wee may perceiv; Theirs to Us bare date (for the moÅ¿t part) Å¿uch a daie of Å¿uch a Moneth, Stylo Novo; Ours to them Å¿uch a daie, Stylo Veteri: And Theirs may bee dated There, by their Accompt, and received here, before they were written by Ours.

For the third Calendar there need not much bee Å¿aid, though it bee more abÅ¿olute then the Å¿econd; for it reduceth the Beginings of the Year to the Emperor's own Time, and Å¿o leaveth the Old Style 13 daies behinde as it ought to do. But it is very rarely found upon the Horizons of anie Globes, neither as yet tranÅ¿lated to anie Common UÅ¿e. In the outermoÅ¿t Limb of the Horizon are Å¿et down the Names
of the 32 Windes of the CompaÅ¿s; to what end will bee Å¿hewed hereafter.

div.head: Why the Meridians and Horizons which are Å¿o Å¿everal upon the Earth, are but Å¿ingle without the Globe.
div.p: THe ReaÅ¿on of this will bee plain, if it bee conÅ¿idered that the Horizons and Meridians, in the uÅ¿e of the Globe, are to be a fitted to anie particular place at pleaÅ¿ure; at Oxford, WoodÅ¿tock, Abingdon, &c. this could never have been don upon the Globe it Å¿elf; for there muÅ¿t a Å¿everal Horizon and a Å¿everal Meridian have paÅ¿Å¿ed through everie Citie, Town, or CaÅ¿tle upon the Globe, which if it had been don, beÅ¿ides the confuÅ¿ion, the Circles would have put out the Places; therefore it was ingenuouÅ¿ly deviÅ¿ed of thoÅ¿e who firÅ¿t thought upon it, to Å¿et one Meridian and one Horizon without the Globe to Å¿erv for all: For in this caÅ¿e the Globe it Å¿elf may bee turned and applied to the Horizon and Meridian with as much eaÅ¿, as the Horizon and Meridian with impoÅ¿Å¿ibilitie could not bee applied to the Globe, as it will hereafter more plainly appear, then it can do yet.

div.head: Of the Quadrant of Altitude, and the CompaÅ¿s.
div.p:
MOreover then the Circles framed without the Globe, two other Appendents are to bee noted upon; the one relating to the Meridian, the other to the Horizon: the firÅ¿t is the Quadrant of Altitude, and is a thin braÅ¿s Plate repreÅ¿enting the fourth part of a Great Circle, and Å¿o divided into 90 Degrees, called therefore the Quadrant; and the Quadrant of Altitude, becauÅ¿ it meaÅ¿ureth the height of the Stars upon the Celestial Globe, to which it moÅ¿t properly
belongeth. The buÅ¿ineÅ¿s it hath to do in Geographie, is to Å¿et out the Zenith of anie Place, and conÅ¿equently to Å¿hew the Angle of PoÅ¿ition, or Bearing of one Place to another, as hereafter Å¿hall bee taught. It is therefore affixed to the Meridian with a little Screw-pin, to bee removed at pleaÅ¿ure from anie Vertical Point of anie Place, to the Vertical Point of anie other. The Å¿econd is the CompaÅ¿s, which is a Needle touched with a LoadÅ¿tone, and Å¿et in a Box upon the Foot of the Horizon, upon the South Å¿ide, Å¿uch another as wee Å¿ee in ordinarie Pocket Dyals for the Sun. The UÅ¿e of it here (as in thoÅ¿e) is to point out the North and South for the Rectification of the Globe, as Å¿hall bee more plainly Å¿aid hereafter.

div.head: Of the Great Circles upon the Globe, and firÅ¿t of the Meridians.
div.p:
THe Great Circles painted upon the Globe are the Meridians, the Equator, and the Zodiack; where wee muÅ¿t not think much to hear of the Meridians again. That of BraÅ¿s without the Globe is to Å¿erv all turns, and the Globe is framed to applie it Å¿elf thereto. The Meridians upon the Globe will eaÅ¿ily bee perceived to bee of a new and another UÅ¿e. They are either the Great, or the LeÅ¿s; not that the Greater are greater then the LeÅ¿s, for they have all one and the Å¿ame Center, and equally paÅ¿s through the Poles of the Earth: but thoÅ¿e which are called LeÅ¿s, are of leÅ¿s uÅ¿e then that, which is called the Great, though it bee no greater then the reÅ¿t. The Great is otherwiÅ¿e called the Fixt and FirÅ¿t Meridian, to which the LeÅ¿s are Å¿econd, and reÅ¿pectively moveable. The Great Meridian is as it were the Landmark of the whole Sphere, from whence the Longitude of the Earth, or anie part thereof is accounted And it is the onelie Circle, which paÅ¿Å¿ing through the Poles, is graduated or divided into Degrees; not the whole Circle, but the one half, becauÅ¿ the Longitude is to bee reckoned round about the Earth. This Great Meridian might have been
planted in anie place, as at York, or at Richmond, but muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿itie bee Å¿et in one certain place of the Globe or other, as it is in everie Å¿everal Globe, though not in the Å¿ame place in all.

div.head: Concerning the Difference of Geographers in the placing of their Great Meridian, and the CauÅ¿Å¿es pretending thereto.
div.p: IN aÅ¿Å¿igning the place of this FirÅ¿t or Great Meridian, I obÅ¿erv that the Geographers, whatÅ¿oever, Å¿till fix it in the WeÅ¿tern Parts: And the ReaÅ¿ons are, not onely becauÅ¿ thoÅ¿e were more diÅ¿covered then the EaÅ¿tern, to thoÅ¿e who had firÅ¿t to do in this matter; but more eÅ¿pecially for that the Proper Motion of the Sun and Moon is from the WeÅ¿t to the EaÅ¿t, contrarie to their diurnal or dailie Motion; and therefore the EclipÅ¿es of the Moon are to bee obÅ¿erved from that Part, which is the moÅ¿t learned and certain Rule for the finding out of the Longitudes of Places, by obÅ¿erving how much Å¿ooner the EcclipÅ¿ begineth in a Place more or leÅ¿s WeÅ¿t then another. And moreover, whereÅ¿oever they place their Great Meridian, they Å¿till reckon the Longitude from WeÅ¿t to EaÅ¿t, that is, till they com up to 180 Degrees, or the Semicircle; where Å¿om of them Å¿taie and begin the Longitude again towards the EaÅ¿t, calling the firÅ¿t Half, Eastern, the other, WeÅ¿tern Longitude. But this CourÅ¿, howÅ¿oever Artificial enough, yet is not uÅ¿ed by the later Geographers, for they account the Longitudes in the whole Circle throughout from WeÅ¿t, by the EaÅ¿t to WeÅ¿t again, Å¿om few SpaniÅ¿h Geographers excepted, who, in the DeÅ¿criptions of their New Indies, reckon the Longitudes quite contrarie, from EaÅ¿t to WeÅ¿t, but which was thwartly in it Å¿elf, and, in the proof, inconÅ¿iderably don. But as the Geographers well enough agreed in the placing of this Great Meridian in the WeÅ¿tern Parts; Å¿o they have differed much more then it becomed them in aÅ¿Å¿igning out the Particular Place.

The Autor of the Greek Geographie intituled to Ptolomie fixeth the Great Meridian (as Marinus the Tyrian (cited by Him) and the Antients before them) in Hera; The Greek Meridian. or Junonia one of the Fortunate IÅ¿lands, as they were termed of old, from an opinion of Å¿om Å¿ingular BleÅ¿Å¿ings imagined by the Antients upon the Genius of thoÅ¿e Parts. They are now called by the Spaniard, IÅ¿las de Canaria: The Canarie-IÅ¿les, better known to us by the Wines of that Name, for the moÅ¿t part falÅ¿ly Å¿o called. Ptolomie, as Plinie alÅ¿o, out of Juba the Affrican King findeth out but Six of theÅ¿e: but the late DiÅ¿coverers meet with Seven: that is, LanÃ§erotta, Forteventura, Teneriffa, Gomera, Fierro, Patma, and the Gran Canarie, which giveth Name to the reÅ¿t. For the Situation of theÅ¿e IÅ¿lands they lie not as Ptolomie placed them, within one Degree of Longitude, or little leÅ¿s, but more Å¿cattering, and lifted up a little above the Tropick of Cancer about the 30th Degree of the Northern Latitude, in that Part of the WeÅ¿tern (otherwiÅ¿e called the Atlantick) OceÃ¤n which trendeth upon the CoaÅ¿t of Affrick, and are therefore reckoned by Geographers to the Affrican IÅ¿les. This was the furtheÅ¿t part of the Earth diÅ¿covered towards the WeÅ¿t to thoÅ¿e of about Ptolomie's time: therefore the Great Meridian was fixed there, in the IÅ¿le Hera, or Junonia, as then it was called, now Tenariff: And from this Meridian all the Longitudes in the Greek-Geographie are taken.

This the Arabian-Geographers knew well enough;The Arabick Meridian. but holding themÅ¿elvs not to bee inferior (as indeed they were not) either to the Indefatigation or Skill of the Greek-Geographers, they hoped to have the begining of Longitude taken from them, which therefore they appointed to bee drawn up on the uttermoÅ¿t Shoar of the WeÅ¿tern-OceÃ¤n 10 Degrees more EaÅ¿t then that of Ptolomie: Alphraganus chap. 10. but they deceived themÅ¿elvs doubly; for firÅ¿t, Their Meridian would not bee brought into Example by others: and again, It was not Å¿o improvidently intended, as not to Å¿erv themÅ¿elvs. For according to the loÅ¿s, or gains of the Sea upon that Shore, their Longitudes have proved to bee importantly different, rightly enough aÅ¿Å¿ign'd, but falÅ¿ifying with the Place, as
they are juÅ¿tly Å¿erved. There is not, for the preÅ¿ent, anie verie great UÅ¿e to the Geographer of the Arabick-Meridian more then to know it; for the TurkiÅ¿h HiÅ¿tories are not Å¿o completely derived down to us as to DeÅ¿cribe the Territories by Longitude, or Latitude. And for the Arabick-Nubian-Geographie TranÅ¿lated into Latine by the Maronites, though otherwiÅ¿e of a rare, and pretious eÅ¿teem, yet is not commended for this, That the DiÅ¿tances of Places are there Å¿et down by a groÅ¿s MenÅ¿uration of Miles: and John Leos Affrica is not Å¿o well. But when the Learned, and long promiÅ¿ed Geographie of Abulfedea the Prince Å¿hall com to light, there can bee nothing don There, without this Meridian. The Prince Å¿etteth down the Longitude of Mecca 67 Degrees. The Greek Geographie 77: and they are both right, and yet they differ 10 Degrees: for Å¿o much were their Meridian Å¿et EaÅ¿t, or West one then the other. Yet neither is this Meridian preÅ¿ently altogether unuÅ¿eful, for beÅ¿ides the Longitudes of Å¿om places noted by Saracenus, Albategni and others, there is a Catalogue of Cities annexed to the AÅ¿tronomical Tables of the King AlphonÅ¿us accounted all from this Great Meridian, but with this difference, That whereas Abulfedea the Prince Å¿etteth down but 10 Degrees diÅ¿tance betwixt the Fortunate IÅ¿les, and the WeÅ¿tern Shore, the Catalogue reckoneth upon 17, and 30 Minutes: a Difference too great to bee given over to the ReceÅ¿Å¿es of the Ocean from that Shore, and therefore I know not as yet what can bee Å¿aid thereto.

The Magnetical Meridian.Our own Geographers, the later eÅ¿pecially, have affected to tranÅ¿plant this great Meridian out of the Canarie IÅ¿les into the AÃ§ores, or Azores, for Å¿o the Ã§erilla will endure to bee pronounced. They were Å¿o called from AÃ§or, which in the SpaniÅ¿h Tongue Å¿ignifie's a GoÅ¿s-Hawk, from the great number of That Kinde, there found at the firÅ¿t DiÅ¿coverie, though now utterly diÅ¿appearing. And it is no Å¿tranger a thing, then that December Å¿hould bee called by our Saxon Fore-fathers Æ¿olfE Monat, that is, Wolf-Moneth; for that in thoÅ¿e Daies this IÅ¿le was miÅ¿chievouÅ¿ly peÅ¿tered with Å¿uch Wilde-BeaÅ¿ts, and in that Moneth more ragingly,
though now Å¿uch a Å¿ight is grown Å¿o forreign to theÅ¿e parts, that they are looked upon with the StrangeneÅ¿s of a Camel, or an Elephant. The Azores are otherwiÅ¿e termed InÅ¿u;lae Flandricae, or the FlemiÅ¿h IÅ¿les, becauÅ¿ Å¿om of them have been famouÅ¿ly poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed, and firÅ¿t DiÅ¿covered by them. They are now in number Nine: Tercere, St MichaÃ«l, S. Marie, S. George, GratioÅ¿a, Pico, Fayall, Corvo, Flores; they are Å¿ituate in the Å¿ame Atlantick Ocean, but North-WeÅ¿t of the Canaries, and trending more upon the SpaniÅ¿h CoaÅ¿t, under the 39 Degree of Latitude, or therebouts. Through theÅ¿e IÅ¿les the Late Geographers will have the Great Meridian to paÅ¿s, upon this conceit of reconciling the Magnetical Pole to That of the World. Their meaning is, That the Needle of the Mariner's CompaÅ¿s, which touched with the Magnet, or LoadÅ¿tone, in dutie ought to point out true North, and South Poles of the World in all other Places, performeth it onely in theÅ¿e IÅ¿les, whereas for the moÅ¿t part elÅ¿where it Å¿werveth, or maketh a Variation from the true Meridian towards the EaÅ¿t, or WeÅ¿t, according to tht unequal temper of the Great Magnet of the Earth: therefore notwithÅ¿tanding that the Greek Meridian was placed well enough in the Canaries, (as indeed it was, and beÅ¿t of all, becauÅ¿ once fixed there) yet it pleaÅ¿ed them to think that it would bee more Artificial, and Gallant to remove it into the Azores, where (as they would bear us in hand) the Magnetical Needle preciÅ¿ely directeth it Å¿elf towards the North, and South of the Whole Frame without the leaÅ¿t Variation, which might Å¿eem to bee a Natural Meridian, and therefore to bee yielded unto by that of Art, whereÅ¿oever placed before.

This Coincidencie of the Magnetical Meridian with that of the World, Som of them will have to bee in the IÅ¿les Corvo, and Flores, the moÅ¿t WeÅ¿tern: Others in S. MichaÃ«l,
Ridly's TreatiÅ¿e of Magnetical Motions, Chap. 36. Norman's New Attrative, Chap. 9. and S. Marie, the more EaÅ¿tern of the Azores. 'Tis true indeed that the Variation is leÅ¿s in theÅ¿e IÅ¿les, then in Å¿om other Places, yet it is by experience found, that the Needle in Corvo North-WeÅ¿teth 4 Degrees: in S. MichaÃ«l it North-EaÅ¿teth 6 Degrees: And therefore the Great Meridian
Å¿hould rather have been drawn through Fayal, where the Variation is but 3 Degrees to the EaÅ¿t; Or eÅ¿pecially through the Cape of good hope, where the Needle preciÅ¿ely pointeth to the True North without any Variation at all by a River Å¿ide there, which therefore the Portugals have called Rio de las Agulias, The River of the Needles.

But which is more, the Magnetical Needle hath no certain Pole in the Earth at all, and under the verie Å¿ame Meridian is found to varie in Å¿om places but 3, or 4 Degrees; in other 17, and more; and which is worÅ¿ (if it bee true) the Variation it Å¿elf hath been lately charged upon with a verie Å¿trange and Å¿ecret inconÅ¿tancie by the ProfeÅ¿Å¿or in AÅ¿tronomie of GreÅ¿ham-College. Hee Å¿aith that the Variation of the Needle at LimehouÅ¿ near London, which Mr Burrows found to bee 11 Degrees, 15 Minutes, in the year 1580: M Gunter in the year 1622 found it to bee but 6 Degrees 13 Minutes. But Hee himÅ¿elf in the year 1634 found it to bee but 4 Degrees, or verie little more; which in the Å¿pace of 54 years is a difference of 7 Degrees to the LeÅ¿s. So little reaÅ¿on is there why the Greek Meridian Å¿hould give place to the Magnetical, beÅ¿ides the great confuÅ¿ion which muÅ¿t needs follow, as it hath.

The Toletan Meridian.But yet more impertinently, the SpaniÅ¿h DeÅ¿cribers remembred before, not onely account their Longitude from EaÅ¿t to WeÅ¿t, utterly againÅ¿t all other Geographie, but not contented with the Greek, Arabian, or any Magnetical Meridian, muÅ¿t needs reckon their Indies from that of Toledo. But they are verie few that take this courÅ¿, and this Pragmatical Meridian is onely found upon a Map, or two, but hath not as yet gotten (nor is it like to do) any relation to the Globe.

The Greek Meridian again.As the caÅ¿e Å¿tandeth with the Great Meridian, the advice and counÅ¿el of Stevinus a Dutch Geographer is very much to the purpoÅ¿e: That the Great Meridian Å¿hould bee brought back to the Fortunate IÅ¿les again, that one certain IÅ¿le of the Å¿even Å¿hould bee choÅ¿en; and in That, one certain place; Exiguus quidem, Å¿ed notabilis & perpetuus, As Å¿mal, but as notable and perpetual as 'tis poÅ¿Å¿ible. The IÅ¿land hee aÅ¿Å¿igned was Teneriff, thought to bee the Å¿ame with
Ptolomie's Hera, or Junonia. The place Pico de Teide, or el pico, The Peak, a Mountain Å¿o called from the Å¿harpneÅ¿s of the top, and therefore the place is Locus exiguus, as Smal as could bee, and 'tis Perpetual, for Hils are everlaÅ¿ting; and as notable, for by the reports of Å¿om in Julius Scaliger it riÅ¿eth above threeÅ¿core Miles in height, which though it bee more then is generally believed, yet thus much is, That it is the higheÅ¿t Mountain in the World.

This JohnÅ¿on a great MaÅ¿ter of this Art conÅ¿idering with himÅ¿elf, though in his leÅ¿Å¿er Globe of the year 1602 hee had made the Great Meridian to paÅ¿s through the IÅ¿les Corvo and Flores; yet Å¿ince that, in his Greater of the year 1616 hee hath it drawn upon the Peak in Tenariffe, as hee expreÅ¿Å¿eth himÅ¿elf in a void place of the Globe. Onely, whereas hee addeth that by this means the Arabick Meridian, and That of Ptolomie will bee all one upon the matter (which hee Å¿aith was fit to bee admoniÅ¿hed) it muÅ¿t needs bee miÅ¿taken. 'Tis true, that the Canaries lie near upon the CoaÅ¿t of Affrick: But the Arabians mean not this Å¿o much by the uttermoÅ¿t Shore, as the uttermoÅ¿t Points of the WeÅ¿tern Land runing along by the Streights of Gebal Taric, or Taric's Hill, as they rightly (wee Gibralter) call it, where the Pillars of Hercules were Å¿et of old, as our Stories deliver, but of Alexander they Å¿aie, to whom, and not to Hercules the Arabick Nubian Geographer aÅ¿Å¿cribeth this Labor, naming there the verie Artificers which that great King provided himÅ¿elf of to force out the Streight; which may poÅ¿Å¿ibly bee the reaÅ¿on, why the Arabians (over and above their ambition of Change) draw their Great Meridian by this Part, in honor to Alexander, whom therefore they call not Å¿o, but Dhilcarnain, that is, The man of the two Horns, for that hee joined the Ends of the Known World together by thoÅ¿e Pillars in the EaÅ¿t upon one Å¿ide, and theÅ¿e in the WeÅ¿t on the other. Which Å¿eeing it is Å¿o, the Reduceing of the Great Meridian to Tenariff again will bee Å¿o far from cloÅ¿ing with that of the UttermoÅ¿t WeÅ¿tern Shore, that according to the Account of Å¿om they will Å¿tand at 15 Degrees diÅ¿tance one from the other, which alÅ¿o maketh Å¿how
of Å¿om reaÅ¿on of the DiÅ¿agreement betwixt Abulfeda the Prince, and the King AlphonÅ¿us in aÅ¿Å¿igning the difference of the Arabick Meridian from the Greek, the Prince allowing but 10, The Catalogue 17 Degrees, which was noted before.

For any concurrence therefore of the Greek, and Arabick Meridians by this means, wee are not to take the Geographer's word; but nevertheleÅ¿s to embrace this Alteration of his CourÅ¿ in bringing the Greek Meridian to his place again.

The Å¿ame advice of Stevinus is commended and taken by Wil. Bleau (a man very like to, if not the very Å¿ame with JohnÅ¿on himÅ¿elf) Cap. 4 of his firÅ¿t Part, which teacheh the UÅ¿e of the Globes according to the Improper HypotheÅ¿is of Ptolomie (as the Title termeth it) per terram quieÅ¿centem. For the Å¿econd Part maketh good the Å¿ame UÅ¿e of the CeleÅ¿tial and TerreÅ¿trial Spheres by the SuppoÅ¿ition of Copernicus per terram mobilem. His words are Longitudo alicujus loci, &c. The Longitude of anie place is an Arch of the Equator comprehended between two half Meridians, the one paÅ¿Å¿ing through the Place it Å¿elf, the other through the High Mountain called Pico de Teide in Tenariffe, Qui tam in maximo nostro Globo TerreÅ¿tri (Å¿aith hee) quÃ m in variis Tabulis Geographicis Ã nobis editis pro Initio Longitudinis terrae aÅ¿Å¿umptus eÅ¿t, & pro eo in bac deÅ¿criptione Å¿emper aÅ¿Å¿umatur, &c. And 'twill never bee well with Geographie till this bee believed in, and made the common and unchangeable Practice.

div.head: What CourÅ¿ is to bee taken with this Varietie of Meridians, and how followed, or neglected by the Geographers.
div.p:
ANd now if one may make Å¿o bold as to give Law to the Geographers, it cannot bee denied but that the readieÅ¿t and leaÅ¿t entangling waie of reckoning the Longitudes is to meet again upon the firÅ¿t Meridian in Tenariffe, but for want of this, and til it can bee relliÅ¿h't univerÅ¿ally, the likeÅ¿t waie
to the BeÅ¿t is for the DeÅ¿cribers either of the Whole, or any Part of the Earth not to fail of Å¿etting down the Å¿everal Meridians obteining as then. AlÅ¿o the Difference of Longitude betwixt theÅ¿e Meridians, and laÅ¿tly which of thoÅ¿e they mean to go by. If I were to draw up (If I could) a New Geographie of the Whole Earth, This, or the like to this ought to prepare to the DeÅ¿cription.

That the Great Meridian by the moÅ¿t Antient Greek Geographers was made to paÅ¿s through the Fortunate IÅ¿lands, now called The Canaries. M. Speed more particularly profeÅ¿Å¿eth to follow Mercator; as in aÅ¿Å¿igning the Longitude of Oxford, hee Å¿aith, that it is diÅ¿tant from the WeÅ¿t 19 Degrees 20 Minutes by Mercator's MeaÅ¿ure. MichaÃ«l, or from the other in Corvo is not Å¿et down, and yet the Difference is 7 Degrees, and more: But hear laÅ¿tly the Kingdom's Geographer in the Preface to his Britannia. Mercator firÅ¿t of all kept himÅ¿elf to the Greek Meridian, as, Appian, Gemma FriÅ¿ius, Maginus, and others; but underÅ¿tanding by Francis of Deip, an experienced Mariner, that the CompaÅ¿s had no Variation in the IÅ¿lands of Capo Verde. Speed, and the reÅ¿t; although this alÅ¿o was the known Meridian of Å¿om Globes of the very Å¿ame Times; and before that, that is, before they had Å¿et their laÅ¿t hand to their DeÅ¿criptions. div.head: Of the LeÅ¿Å¿er Meridians.
div.p: THe LeÅ¿Å¿er are thoÅ¿e Black Circles, which you Å¿ee to paÅ¿s through the Poles, and Å¿ucceeding to the Great at 10 and 10 Degrees as in moÅ¿t Globes; or as in Å¿om, at 15 and 15 Degrees Difference.

Everie place, never Å¿o little more EaÅ¿t, or WeÅ¿t then another, hath a Å¿everal Meridian. Shot-over hath a diÅ¿tinct Meridian from Oxford, becauÅ¿ more EaÅ¿t; OÅ¿ney hath not the Å¿ame as near as it is, for it lieth WeÅ¿t of the Citie: The exact Meridian whereof muÅ¿t paÅ¿s directly through the middle; yet becauÅ¿ of the huge diÅ¿tance of the Earth from the Heavens, all theÅ¿e Places, and Places much further off may bee Å¿aid to have the Å¿ame Meridian, as the Almanack-makers Calculate their PrognoÅ¿tications to Å¿uch, or Å¿uch a Meridian where they pretend to make their ObÅ¿ervations: But Å¿aie too, that it may generally Å¿erv, &c. And indeed there is no verie Å¿enÅ¿ible Difference in leÅ¿s then 60 Miles, upon which ground the Geographers, as the Astronomers allow a New Meridian to everie other Degree of the Equator, which would
bee 130 in all, but except the Globes were made of an Extreme and UnuÅ¿eful Diameter, Å¿o manie would Å¿tand too thick for the DeÅ¿cription. Therefore moÅ¿t commonly they put down but 18; that is at 10 Degrees diÅ¿tance one from the other, the Å¿pecial uÅ¿e of theÅ¿e LeÅ¿Å¿er Meridians beeing to make a quicker diÅ¿patch in the account of the Longitudes. Som others, as Mercator Å¿et down but 12 at 15 Degrees difference, aiming at this, That the Meridians might bee diÅ¿tant one from the other a full part of time, or an hour: for Å¿eeing that the Sun is carried 15 Degrees off the Equinoctial everie hour, as was Å¿aid before. The Meridians Å¿et at that DiÅ¿tance muÅ¿t make an hours difference in the RiÅ¿ing or Setting of the Sun to the Å¿everal places, as if the Sun RiÅ¿e at Å¿uch an hour, Å¿uch a daie of the year at Oxford. In a place 15 Degrees more diÅ¿tant towards the EaÅ¿t the Sun riÅ¿eth an hour Å¿ooner. In a place 15 Degrees diÅ¿tant towards the WeÅ¿t, an hour later, the Å¿ame daie of this, or that year.

Now becauÅ¿ the Spaces of time are reckoned by the Å¿ame Degrees of the Equator as the DiÅ¿tances of Place, The Degrees of Longitude have been called Tempora; which word Camden Å¿omtimes delighteth to uÅ¿e, as in the Longitude of Bath hee Å¿aith it is 20 Temporibus, 20 Times, that is 20 Degrees diÅ¿tant from the Great Meridian.
