div.head: Of the Equator, and the LeÅ¿Å¿er Circles.
div.p: THe Equator is the Middle Circle betwixt two Poles graduated throughout, and plainly dividing the Globe into two equal Parts, from North to South, This is the Circle of Longitude, as the Meridian of Latitude; for Longitude is reckoned in the Equator from the Meridian: Latitude in the Meridian from the Equator.

CroÅ¿Å¿ing this Circle obliquely in the Middle is the Zodiack, the utttermoÅ¿t extent whereof towards the North noteth out the Tropick of Cancer; towards the South, the
Tropick of Capricorn, each of them diÅ¿tant from the Equator 23 Degrees, or not much more, as may bee accounted in the Great Meridian. Equi-diÅ¿tant from theÅ¿e, and at the Å¿ame diÅ¿tance from the Poles as the Tropicks from the Equator, are Å¿et down the Artick and Antartick Circles; all offering themÅ¿elvs to Å¿ight by their Names, and diÅ¿tinction of Bredth, and Color, more notably then the reÅ¿t: by the reÅ¿t I mean the black blinder Circles equi-diÅ¿tantly remooved from the Equator at 10 Degrees difference, and Å¿erving the Å¿ame turn in the accounting of Latitude, as the Meridians at the Å¿ame diÅ¿tance in the reckoning of the Longitude. And theÅ¿e are called the unnamed Parallels.
And Å¿o much of the DeÅ¿cription of the Earth and Water together; Now of the Waterie-Part by it Å¿elf.

div.head: The DeÅ¿cription of the Waterie-Part of the Globe by the Rumbes of the Mariner's CompaÅ¿s.
div.p:
THe CourÅ¿ of a Ship upon the Sea dependeth upon the Windes. The DeÅ¿ignation of theÅ¿e, upon the certain Knowledg of one Principal; which conÅ¿idering the Situation and condition of the whole Sphere, ought in nature to bee North, or South. The North to us upon this Å¿ide of the Line, the South to thoÅ¿e in the other HemiÅ¿phere; for in making this obÅ¿ervation; Men were to intend themÅ¿elvs towards one fixed part of the Heavens, or other, and therefore to the one of theÅ¿e In the South Part there is not found anie Star Å¿o notable, and of Å¿o near a diÅ¿tance from the Pole, as to make anie preciÅ¿e or firm Direction of that Winde. But in the North wee have that of the Å¿econd Magnitude in the Tail of the LeÅ¿Å¿er Bear, making Å¿o Å¿mal, and, for the Motion, Å¿o inÅ¿enÅ¿ible a Circle about the Pole, that it cometh all to one, as if it were the Pole it Å¿elf. This pointed out the North-winde to the Mariners of old eÅ¿pecially; and was therefore called by Å¿om the Load, or Lead-Star. But this could bee onely in the night, and not alwaies then. It is now more conÅ¿tantly and Å¿urely Å¿hewed by the Needle
touched with the Magnete, which is therefore called the Load or LeadÅ¿tone, for the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on of the leading and directing their CourÅ¿es: in the Nature and Secret of which Stone, becauÅ¿ the whole buÅ¿ineÅ¿s of Navigation is Å¿o throughly concern'd, Å¿omthing is to bee borrowed out of that PhiloÅ¿ophie.

div.head: The Original of the Mariner's CompaÅ¿s from the Magnetical ConÅ¿titution of the Earth.
div.p: A Magnetical Bodie is deÅ¿cribed to bee That, which hanging in the AÃ«rial or Aetherial Parts of the UniverÅ¿, firmly Å¿eateth it Å¿elf upon it's own Poles, in a Situation natural and unchangeable, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting alÅ¿o of Å¿om Å¿uch parts as Å¿eparated from the reÅ¿t can take upon them the nature and conditions of the whole.

Under this DeÅ¿cription the Magnetical PhiloÅ¿ophers comprehend the Globes of Saturn, Jupiter, the Sun, &c. but becauÅ¿ theÅ¿e Bodies are placed Å¿o far above the reach of our Experience, and purpoÅ¿e; it Å¿hall bee Å¿ufficient to make the DeÅ¿cription good upon the Earth.

To do this, I think I may Å¿uppoÅ¿e, FirÅ¿t, that the ConÅ¿titution of the Whole Earth may bee gathered from the prevailing parts, Å¿uch parts eÅ¿pecially as do bear upon them the Marks and Signatures of the Whole.

Then Å¿econdly, That the parts of the Earth, which lie couched about the Center, are not of a different or degenerous compliance from theÅ¿e which lie Å¿cattered about the Surface; which if anie bodie liÅ¿t to raiÅ¿ Å¿uÅ¿picions upon, as Mr White hath don, they may; but I am Å¿ure they were no nearer Him, when hee lai'd the Foundations of the Earth, then wee.

The prevailing parts about the Surface of the Earth, are the Mines of LoadÅ¿tone, Steel, Iron, &c. of all which, it is certain, that they are indued with a virtue Magnetical, which enableth them to place themÅ¿elvs in a Å¿et poÅ¿ition betwixt North and South: And not onely theÅ¿e, but even Claie it Å¿elf, burnt to Brick, and cooled North and South, if it bee hanged up in a cloÅ¿e place, and left to it's libertie, will Å¿eat it Å¿elf in the Å¿ame Situation.

But the moÅ¿t vigorous Magnetes are the Stone and the Steel, the Stone eÅ¿pecially: And the Steel hath a capacitie to receiv a Å¿tronger virtue from the Stone, whereby it more firmly Å¿eateth it Å¿elf in the North and South-PoÅ¿ition of the Earth, directly pointing out thoÅ¿e Windes to the Mariner; not in all parts directly, becauÅ¿ in following the ConÅ¿titution of the Great Magnete of the Whole Earth, it muÅ¿t needs bee here and there led aÅ¿ide towards the EaÅ¿t or WeÅ¿t, by the unequal temper of the Globe, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting more of Water then of Earth in Å¿om places, and of Earth more or leÅ¿s Magnetical in others.

This Deviation of the Needle, the Mariners call North-EaÅ¿ting, or North-WeÅ¿ting, as it falleth out to bee; otherwiÅ¿e and more Artificially, the Variation of the CompaÅ¿s; which though it pretend uncertainly, yet proveth to bee one of the greateÅ¿t helps the Sea man hath; for the Degrees of Variation, which the place it Å¿elf exactly obÅ¿erved, giveth him a Å¿hrewd gueÅ¿s of the Å¿ame, when hee meeteth with the Å¿ame Variation again, unleÅ¿s the Variation it Å¿elf Å¿hould bee Å¿ubject to a Change of Admirable Diminutions as the Late DiÅ¿coverer calleth it in his DiÅ¿courÅ¿ Mathematical, &c.

This Needle, touched with the Stone, and directing towards the North and South, the Mariners (as the Magnetical PhiloÅ¿ophers) call their Directorie-Needle,
Mr Henrie Gellibrand. not onely for the reaÅ¿on intimated, but to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h it alÅ¿o from their other, called the Inclinatorie-Needle, becauÅ¿ it is alÅ¿o found that the Needle touched with the Stone, will not onely turn towards the North, but make an Inclination under the Horizon, as to conform with the Diameter or Axis of the Earth.

This Motion of the Needle was accidentally diÅ¿covered by Robert Norman, a Man of great dexteritie in the framing and dreÅ¿Å¿ing up of the Mariner's CompaÅ¿s. It hapned to him, that, as often as hee had finiÅ¿hed his Needles, and equally poized them upon their Pins, hee had no Å¿ooner touched them with the Stone, but Å¿till the North-Point of the Needle would forÅ¿ake the parallel Site in which hee had placed it, and incline it Å¿elf to the Axis of the Earth. The reaÅ¿on whereof not preÅ¿ently perceiv'd, eÅ¿caped a while, with a conceit, as if the Artificer had deceived himÅ¿elf in ballancing
the Needle; which therefore hee endeavoured to correct with a little peice of Wax Å¿tuck upon the lighter End (as hee took it to bee) till at laÅ¿t, beeing imploied in the framing of a CompaÅ¿s, the Needle whereof was to bee 6 inches in length, and having poliÅ¿hed and levelled it with all poÅ¿Å¿ible care, and yet after the touching of it with the Stone, finding one end to weigh down the other, hee was forced to cut off Å¿om part of the heavier end, (as hee Å¿till miÅ¿took it) and Å¿o more, till hee had made the Needle unÅ¿erviceable: whereupon, conÅ¿ulting with Å¿om knowing Friends, hee was adviÅ¿ed to make Å¿om InÅ¿truments to trie out the experience. And it was found to bee this verie Inclination to the Axis of the Earth, and proportionably, though not equally, anÅ¿wering to the Degrees of Latitude.
But this Inclination alÅ¿o, as the Direction, is variable, and for the Å¿ame cauÅ¿Å¿es of the Earth's unequal temper.
But all that which I have Å¿aid will more evidently and expertly appear, upon the Terrella, or little Earth of Load-Å¿tone.

As the Great Magnete of the Earth, Å¿o everie Magnetical part thereof, and everie part of that, hath Poles, Axis, Equator, Meridians, and Parallels of it's own. The Magnetical PhiloÅ¿ophers therefore, to repreÅ¿ent unto themÅ¿elvs the Great Nature of the Whole, take a Å¿trong Å¿mall piece of a Rock, which having reduced into a Globous form, they firÅ¿t found out the Poles by the filings of Steel (or otherwiÅ¿e) which will all meet together upon the North and South Points. A Circle drawn equidiÅ¿tantly from theÅ¿e deÅ¿cribeth the Equator. This don, they take a Å¿mal Steel wyer, of about half an inch long, and applie it to anie part of the Equator, and it will preciÅ¿ely turn towards the North and South Poles, which is Motion of Direction, and marketh out the Meridians of the Terrella. But Å¿uppoÅ¿ing a Concavitie to bee let into this Little Earth, in anie part, either about the Equator, or betwixt it and the Poles: In that caÅ¿e the Needle will not point directly to the Poles, but will make a Variation; unleÅ¿s it bee placed exactly towards the Middle of the Concavitie, and then it maketh no Variation at all, but turneth directly, as
before; which from the CauÅ¿Å¿es juÅ¿tifieth the Directions, and Variations of the CompaÅ¿s, towards and from the Poles of the Earth.

Remove this Wyer from the Equator towards the Pole, and the one End of it will riÅ¿e up as Norman's Needle did, and the other End will Å¿tick down upon the Stone, making an Acute Angle, and deÅ¿cribing a Parallel. Remove it nearer to the Pole, and the Angle will bee leÅ¿s and leÅ¿s acute, till at a a certain Parallel it becom a Right Angle to the Stone. Remove it yet nearer, and the Angle will bee Recto Major, or more and more obtuÅ¿e. Bring it up to the Pole it Å¿elf, and it will there Å¿tand bolt upright, and make one Line with the Axis of the Stone; which maketh good the Inclination of the Needle to the Diameter of the Great Magnete: for if Norman had touched his Needle under the Line, it would have Å¿tood level upon the Pin without anie Declination at all. If hee had touched it in anie place beyond the Line, the Inclination, would have been on the South Å¿ide; but living here more towards this Pole, it muÅ¿t needs fall out as hee found it. Nobile experimentum, as Dr Gilbert cal's it, and hee is bold to Å¿aie, ut nullius unquam rationis aut mentis compos, &c. that hee who had conÅ¿idered of this, and holdeth not himÅ¿elf convinced of the Principles of Magnetical PhiloÅ¿ophie, is not to bee taken for a man of Å¿enÅ¿ or reaÅ¿on. I know what Scaliger Å¿aith to this; Gilbertus Medicus, &c. tres ampliÅ¿Å¿imos Commentarios edidit, in quibus magÃ¬s mihi probavit Doctrinam Å¿uam, quÃ m Magnetis Naturam; nam incertior Å¿um quÃ m dudum. Wee know what hee meaneth by ampliÅ¿simos: but why tres Commentarios? Sure the Man had not read all his Books, for the Dr wrote Å¿ix: but England was a kinde of Nazareth to this Great Scholar; hee would not endure anie good Å¿hould com out from hence.

But to give the Art and the Nation but their due:Norman Burrough wright Gilbert Ridley Barlow Gill â¢ b â¢ and As there is no point of PhiloÅ¿ophie Å¿o admirable and Å¿ecret with Nature as this; Å¿o none Å¿o immerÅ¿t in viÅ¿ible practice and experiment, and bred up from the verie Cradle to that growth and Å¿tature, which now it hath in this verie Corner of the World, by EngliÅ¿h Men.

Manie other Experiments of great Wonder and Satisfaction are made by the Magnetical PhiloÅ¿ophers upon the Stone; but to the purpoÅ¿e I Å¿peak of, theÅ¿e are the Principal, which is, to give the ReaÅ¿ons of the Needles turning towards the North and South, which is the Original of the Mariner's CompaÅ¿s.

The North and South Windes thus aÅ¿Å¿ured by the Motion either of Direction or Variation of the Needle, The Mariner Å¿uppoÅ¿eth his Ship to bee, as it alwaies is, upon Å¿om Horizon or other. The Center whereof is that of the Ship.

The Line of North and South found out by the Needle, a Line croÅ¿Å¿ing this at right Angles Å¿heweth the EaÅ¿t and WeÅ¿t, and Å¿o they have the 4 Cardinal Windes; and the Indian They are drawn upon a white China diÅ¿h filled with Water, upon the Center whereof there hangeth a Needle of 6 inches long. CompaÅ¿s conÅ¿iÅ¿teth of no more. CroÅ¿s again each of theÅ¿e Lines, and they have the 8 Whole Windes, as they call them. Another DiviÅ¿ion of theÅ¿e maketh 8 more, which they call the Half Windes. A third maketh 16, which they call the Quarter Windes; Å¿o they are 32 in all. Martin Cortez noteth, that Å¿om Mariners of his time divided that DiviÅ¿ion over again, and Å¿o the CompaÅ¿s conÅ¿iÅ¿ted of 64 Windes: but hee noteth alÅ¿o, that this DiviÅ¿ion was more exact then for the UÅ¿e. Everie one of theÅ¿e Windes is otherwiÅ¿e termed a Å¿everal point of the CompaÅ¿s, and the Whole Line conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of 2 Windes, as the Line of North and South, or that of East and WeÅ¿t, is called a Rombe. The Spaniards firÅ¿t gave that Name, as Peter of Medina taketh it upon them; yet not out of their own Language, but fancying to themÅ¿elvs that the Lines of the CompaÅ¿s (as indeed they do) much reÅ¿embled the Spars of a Spining Wheel, which in Latine is called Rhombus, from the Greek ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , to turn about, they call thoÅ¿e Lines Rumbos: and the Word hath taken.

The CompaÅ¿s therefore is an Horizontical DiviÅ¿ion of the 32 Windes, upon a round piece of PaÅ¿teboard Å¿et in a Box, in the Center whereof upon a pin of Laten cinque bored, the Needle or Wyers, firÅ¿t touched with the Stone, are placed. This Box hangeth in another Box, between two hoops of Laten, that however the outermoÅ¿t Box bee toÅ¿Å¿ed up and down by the Motion of the Ship, yet the innermoÅ¿t may alwaies hang
level to the Horizon. It is placed in the middle of the Pupe, upon a right Line imagined to paÅ¿s by the Main-maÅ¿t through the Center of the Ship, and Å¿o putteth the Pilot in his Waie.

TheÅ¿e CompaÅ¿Å¿es are repreÅ¿ented, as they may upon the Globe, by thoÅ¿e Circles which you Å¿ee divided into 32 Parts with their FleurÃ§ de Lis, alwaies pointing to the North. And though the Windes are not Å¿et down by Name, yet they may bee fetched from the Horizon without the Globe. And the Rumbes are drawn out at length circularly, if the CourÅ¿ bee upon a Meridian, the Equator, or anie other parallel; otherwiÅ¿e they are HeliÅ¿pherical Lines, as they call them, that is, partly Circular, and partly Helical or Spiral, as you may Å¿ee them deÅ¿cribed upon the Globe.

In the Globes Å¿et out by SaunderÅ¿on and Molineux, you have the CourÅ¿es of Sr Francis Drake, and FourbiÅ¿her's Voyages; and in JanÅ¿on's Globe that of Oliver Van-Nort deÅ¿cribed by the Rumbes, whereby you may judg of the reÅ¿t.

The Knowledg of all this is not of leÅ¿s uÅ¿e to the Geographer, then the other DeÅ¿cription by Circles; aÅ¿wel for the Reading of Sea-Voyages and DiÅ¿coveries of New Lands and PaÅ¿Å¿ages, as for that the verie DeÅ¿criptions of the Earth, for a great part, cannot bee made without references to the Water.

As the Earth and Water are wholly repreÅ¿ented upon the Globe, Å¿o the whole, JanÅ¿on's Globe of the Year 1616. The Great Meridian paÅ¿Å¿eth by the Pike in Tenariff. The LeÅ¿Å¿er Å¿tand at 10 Degrees diÅ¿tance. or anie part of either may bee deÅ¿cribed in Plano, or upon a plane Surface in a Map or Sea-Chart. And of theÅ¿e alÅ¿o Å¿omthing Å¿hall bee diÅ¿courÅ¿ed hereafter; for the preÅ¿ent,
Thus much of the DeÅ¿cription: now followeth

div.head: The UÅ¿e of the TerreÅ¿trial Globe; and firÅ¿t of the Rectification.
div.p: THe firÅ¿t care of this is to Å¿ee that the Foot of the Globe Å¿tand level or parallel to the Horizon; for which purpoÅ¿e Å¿om Globes have a Plumb-line, and there bee that adviÅ¿e for a Triangular Level of Wood, with a Plummet for the purpoÅ¿e, to bee applied to anie part of the Horizon, after the manner as the Mechanicks trie their Planes: but the matter is not tied to Å¿uch a Å¿everitie of exactneÅ¿s, but that a good Eie may paÅ¿s for a Å¿ufficient Judg. The next thing is, that it bee placed in the North and South-PoÅ¿ition of the Earth as directly as it may. This dependeth upon the knowledg of the Meridian of the place, but may well enough bee don by a Needle, whoÅ¿e Variation is known, Å¿uch an one as is uÅ¿ed to bee Å¿et upon the South Å¿ide of the Foot of Å¿om Globes, for the Å¿ame purpoÅ¿e: then lift up the North-Pole above the Horizon Å¿o manie Degrees as will anÅ¿wer to the Latitude of the Place unto which you mean to rectifie, which Å¿uppoÅ¿e to bee Oxford, therefore the Pole is to bee lifted up 51 Degrees, for that is the Elevation of this Place: then finde out Oxford in the Globe, and bring it to the BraÅ¿s Meridian, and there Å¿taie it with a piece of paper, or the like, put between the Meridian and the Globe: And you have Å¿et before you Oxford with the verie Å¿ame and all reÅ¿pects of Situation upon the Globe, as it hath upon the Earth it Å¿elf. And this is called Rectification, or right Å¿etting of the Globe.

div.head: By the known Place to finde out the Longitude and Latitude, and by the known Longitude and Latitude to finde out the Place.
div.p: THeÅ¿e Terms of Longitude and Latitude are underÅ¿tood either of the Å¿ame or Å¿everal Places. In the firÅ¿t Å¿enÅ¿ they are abÅ¿olutely called the Longitude or Latitude of this or that place. In the other Å¿enÅ¿ wee uÅ¿e to Å¿ay, The Difference of Longitude or Latitude between Å¿uch and Å¿uch a place. The Longitude of this or that place is the diÅ¿tance of it from the Great Meridian, to the Meridian of the Place reckoned in the Degrees of the Equator. The Latitude of a Place is the DiÅ¿tance of the Equator from the parallel of the place reckoned in the Degrees of the Meridian. Therefore if the place met with bee under the Great Meridian, it hath no Longitude at all, as the Hill in Tenariffe, unleÅ¿s it bee in reÅ¿pect of Å¿om other Great Meridian, as that by Corvo, or the other by St MichaÃ«l; and of Å¿uch a place it will bee Å¿ufficient to know the Latitude. So again, if the place met with bee under the Equator, it hath no Latitude at all; and of Å¿uch a place it Å¿hall bee Å¿ufficient to know the Longitude. But if the place Å¿hould fall out to bee in the verie InterÅ¿ection it Å¿elf of the Equator, and the Great Meridian it hath neither Latitude nor Longitude; and of Å¿uch a Place it is Å¿ufficiently Å¿aid, that There it is.

But if the known Place lie at anie diÅ¿tance from the Equator, it is but bringing it up to the BraÅ¿s Meridian, and the Latitude is found by obÅ¿erving what Degrees the Meridian Å¿etteth off. Let Oxford bee the Place you meet with, turn the Globe till it lie preciÅ¿ely under the Meridian, and you will finde from the Equator 51 Degrees, 32 Minutes of Northern Latitude; and, by conÅ¿equence, you alÅ¿o have the Elevation of the Pole: for that is alwaies equal to the Latitude of the Place.

With the Å¿ame labor you may finde out the Longitude, if holding Å¿till the Globe you obÅ¿erv the Degrees of InterÅ¿ection
cut off by the Meridian in the Equator: as put the caÅ¿e for Oxford Å¿till, it will bee found 22 Degrees from the Fortunate IÅ¿lands, Å¿aith Camden; from St MichaÃ«l in the Azores 'tis exactly true by which the Preface promiÅ¿ed to go; but from the Fortunate IÅ¿les or the Pike in Tenariffe, not out 15.

In caÅ¿e anie of the leÅ¿Å¿er Meridians happen to paÅ¿s through the Place, you may rekon of what number it is from the Great Meridian, as whether it bee the 3d, 5th, 9th, &c. and Å¿o manie times 10 Degrees, (for at that diÅ¿tance they are Å¿et) is the Longitude of the Place. The Å¿ame courÅ¿ may bee taken by the Parallels to account the Degrees of Latitude.

And as the Longitude and Latitude are found out by the Place known, Å¿o after the Å¿ame manner anie Place may bee found out by the fore-knowledg of them. This fore-knowledg was firÅ¿t had by ObÅ¿ervation of the EclipÅ¿es of the Moon, and the Meridian Altitude of the Sun or Stars, but may bee now more eaÅ¿ily gotten out of the Tables of Peter Appian, Gemma FriÅ¿ius, Mercator, Ortelius, Tycho, and that annexed to Mr Hues his TreatiÅ¿e of the UÅ¿e of the Globes, wherein the Longitudes and Latitudes of all the Principal Cities, Capes, Rivers, &c. are Å¿et down, but not accounting all from the Å¿ame Meridian, which therefore alÅ¿o muÅ¿t bee conÅ¿idered off: For the named Autors, Appian, Gemma FriÅ¿ius, and Tycho reckoned from the Canaries, the reÅ¿t from St MichaÃ«l in the Azores.

div.head: Of the Difference of Longitude and Latitude, and what is to bee obÅ¿erved in the converting of the Degrees of either into Miles.
div.p:
THe ReÅ¿pect of Å¿everal Places one to another, is called the Difference of Longitude or Latitude, as the Latitude of Oxford is 51 Degrees, the Latitude of Durham 55. The Difference of Latitude is 4 Degrees. The UÅ¿e of Longitude and Latitude, in the abÅ¿olute Å¿enÅ¿, was to make out the PoÅ¿ition of anie Place, in reÅ¿pect of the Whole Sphere. In this other
meaning, the Intent is to Å¿hew the Situation and DiÅ¿tance of anie Place from and in reÅ¿pect of anie other. The Situation of a Place to another Place, is otherwiÅ¿e called the Angle of PoÅ¿ition; but of the Distance firÅ¿t, and how that is to bee made into Miles.

The Å¿everal caÅ¿es put by the Geographers of this Difference, are either of Places differing in Latitude onely, or Longitude onely, or both. Places differing in latitude onely, are all Å¿uch as lie under the Å¿ame Meridian, but Å¿everal Parallels. This may Å¿o fall out, as that either both the Places may bee in North, or both in South Latitude, or one of them in each. If both the Places lie in North or South Latitude, then it is plain, that if the leÅ¿Å¿er Latitude bee Å¿ubduced from the greater, the Remanent of Degrees, multiplied into Miles by 60, Å¿heweth the DiÅ¿tance, as the IÅ¿l' de Maio in the Latitude of 14 Degrees; and the IÅ¿le of St MichaÃ«l 39 Degrees, are both under the Å¿ame Meridian: the 14 Degrees are the leÅ¿Å¿er Latitude, which taken from the 39 the greater, the remainder is 25, which multiplied by 60, giveth the DiÅ¿tance in Miles. If one of the Places lie in North, the other in South Latitude, add the Degrees of both Latitudes together, and do the like.

The verie Å¿ame CourÅ¿ is to be taken, if the Places differ in Longitude onely, in caÅ¿e they both lie under the Line it Å¿elf, becauÅ¿ there the meaÅ¿ure is in a Great Circle, as in the Meridians of Latitude; but if otherwiÅ¿e it fall out to bee in anie Parallel, on this or that Å¿ide of the Line, the caÅ¿e is altered.

Wee take for inÅ¿tance the Difference of Longitude betwixt London and Charlton, or Charls-Town, in Charlton IÅ¿land, Å¿o honored with the Name of CHARLS Prince of WALES, by Captain Thomas James, at his Attempt upon the North-WeÅ¿t PaÅ¿Å¿age in the Wintering, the 29th of Maie, the Year 1632, which was the Daie of His HighneÅ¿s Nativitie.

The Difference of Longitude is 79 Degrees, 30 Minutes, as it was taken from an EclipÅ¿ of the Moon, obÅ¿erved there by the Learned Captain, Octob. 29, 1631, and by Mr Henrie Gellibrand at GreÅ¿ham College at the Å¿ame time. It is required that this Difference of Longitude bee converted into Miles.

The Latitude of Charlton is 52 Degrees, 3 Minutes; that of London much about the Å¿ame. Here the proportion of 60 Miles to a Degree, will over-reckon the Distance almoÅ¿t by the half. The reaÅ¿on whereof Å¿hall bee firÅ¿t reported out of the Nature of the Sphere.

However it bee certain, that the Artificial Globe (as the Natural is Å¿uppoÅ¿ed to bee) is of a Form preciÅ¿ely round, and may bee drawn upon all over with Great Circles Meridionally, yet conÅ¿idered from the Middle Line to the Poles, it hath a Å¿enÅ¿ible Inclination or DepreÅ¿Å¿ion of Sphere, as it is termed in their words, Å¿o that if the Artificial Globe bee turned about upon it's Axel, Å¿everal parts of the Å¿ame Bodie Å¿hall bee more Å¿wiftly moved then other at the Å¿ame time; for it is plain, that the Equator is moved about in the Å¿ame duration of time, as the Å¿malleÅ¿t Parallel, but the Circumferences are of a VaÅ¿t and ViÅ¿ible DiÅ¿proportion, and therefore is not poÅ¿Å¿ible they Å¿hould go an equal pace.

It is upon the Å¿ame grounds, that the Autor of the Æ²Å¿e of the Globe per Terram mobilem will tell you, that in the Diurnal Motion of the Earth, though Amsterdam (in the Å¿ame Latitude with Oxford) keep pace with the IÅ¿le of St Thomas under the Line, yet they are of a very different diÅ¿patch; for AmÅ¿terdam goeth but 548 Miles in an hour, whereas the IÅ¿le of St Thomas poÅ¿teth over 900 Miles in the Å¿ame Å¿pace of time, which is after the rate of 12 Miles in a Minute, and more. And all this is true (that is true to the Paradox) from the Inclination of the Sphere: But more plainly yet.

Wee Å¿ee that the Meridians upon the Globe are Å¿et at 10 Degrees DiÅ¿tance, but wee may perceiv too that this DiÅ¿tance groweth leÅ¿s and leÅ¿s, as the Meridians draw nearer towards their concurrence in the Poles, as the Globe it Å¿elf doth from the Equator upwards, and therefore the Degrees however accounted proportionable, yet cannot poÅ¿Å¿ibly bee equal in the LeÅ¿Å¿er Parallels to thoÅ¿e in the Equator, but muÅ¿t needs make an orderlie Diminution from thence to either of the Poles.

When therefore it was formerly Å¿aid that 60 Miles of the Surface of the Earthlie Globe anÅ¿wer to a degree in the Heaven,
it is to bee underÅ¿tood of the Degrees of a Great Circle, and Å¿o is alwaies true in thoÅ¿e of Latitude, but in the Degrees of Longitude it holdeth onely in the Equator it Å¿elf, but in the Parallels more North, or South the proportion diminiÅ¿heth from 60 to none at all. So that if I would convert the Longitudes of the Molucca's, or anie other parts under the Line into Miles, it is but multiplying the Degrees of Longitude by 60 and the thing is don; but if I would do the like by Oxford, or anie other place betwixt the Equator and the Poles, I muÅ¿t firÅ¿t know what number of Miles anÅ¿wereth to a Degree in that Parallel of Latitude. The knowledg of this dependeth upon the proportion which the Equator beareth to the Parallels, which is learned out by the skill of Trigonometrie, but need not now bee Å¿o hardly attained to; for the Proportions are alreadie caÅ¿t up into a Table by Peter Appian in the firÅ¿t Part of his CoÅ¿mographie. They are there Å¿et down according to the Rate of German Miles, one of which maketh 4 of ours. According to our own Rate they are as followeth:

table.head: The Proportion of EngliÅ¿h Miles anÅ¿wering to their Å¿everal Degrees of Latitude.

div.p: KNowing then the Latitude of Charlton to bee 52 Degrees, and that of London much about the Å¿ame: I enter the Table, where I finde the Sum of 36 Miles, or thereabouts to anÅ¿wer a Degree of that Parallel, therefore muliplying the Degrees of Longitude by 36, it giveth up the number of Miles from the Great Meridian to the Place.

And very fit it were that theÅ¿e Proportions were written upon the Horizon of the TerreÅ¿trial Globes, rather then the Calendars. And what elÅ¿ there is, confeÅ¿Å¿ed by themÅ¿elvs to belong of right to the other Globe, and of little uÅ¿e to the Geographer, till this will bee, they may bee cut upon a Silver-Plate, or Ruler of Box, or Å¿om how, or other; for without this Table, the UÅ¿e of the Globe, as to this CaÅ¿e of Difference, is as good as none at all.

The laÅ¿t CaÅ¿e is remaining, which is put of Å¿uch Places as differ both in Longitude and Latitude; for the conÅ¿ideration whereof the Geographers have deviÅ¿ed Å¿everal waies, as the Arithmetical waie; That by the Sphaerical Triangles, by the Semi-circle, &c. But the working by either of theÅ¿e is of more time and intricacie then was to bee wiÅ¿hed. The readieÅ¿t of all, and not much inferior to the certaintie of the reÅ¿t is the Geometrical waie, as Peter Appian (one of the Fathers of this Art) hath termed it; and 'tis no more but this: Let the two Places bee the IÅ¿le of St Thomas and Tenariff in the Canaries. Take your CompaÅ¿Å¿es and Å¿et one Foot of them in Tenariff, the other in S. Thomas, and keeping the Feet of the CompaÅ¿Å¿es at the Å¿ame diÅ¿tance, remove them to the Equator, or Great Meridian, and Å¿ee how many Degrees they Å¿et off; for that number multiplied by 60 is the DiÅ¿tance of the two Places in Miles. The ground of this Rule is, that the DiÅ¿tance of all Places not differing onely in Longitude, are to bee underÅ¿tood to bee in a Great Circle, and it was known before, that the Degrees of Å¿uch a one are Å¿everally anÅ¿wered by 60 of our Miles upon the face of the Earth. You may do the like in the Quadrant of Altitude as will bee Å¿een in the next Invention.

div.head: To finde out the Bearing of one Place from another, and what is meant by the Angle of PoÅ¿ition.
div.p:
THe Zenith is the Pole of the Horizon through which the AÅ¿tronomers imagin Circles drawn (as the Meridians through the Poles of the World) Å¿o dividing the Degrees of the Horizon as to mark out the Site of the Stars from this or that CoaÅ¿t of the World. And becauÅ¿ theÅ¿e Circles are Å¿uppoÅ¿ed to bee drawn through the Semt, or Semith Alros, that is The Point over the Head, or Vertical Point, The Arabians called them AlÅ¿emuth, we cal them Å¿til Azimuths. And for that the Zenith Point Å¿till altereth with the Horizon, theÅ¿e Circls could not have been deÅ¿crib'd upon the Globes, but are repreÅ¿ented there by the Quadrant of Altitude, which is the 4th part of anie one of thoÅ¿e, and moÅ¿t properly Å¿erving the other Globe, yet upon the Å¿ame ground is uÅ¿eful to the Geograher in Å¿etting out that Angle which is made by the meeting of the Meridian of anie Place, with the Vertical Circle of anie other and of the Å¿ame, called therefore the Angle of PoÅ¿ition, or Site. To finde this out you are to elevate the Pole to the Latitude of one of the Places, then bring the Place to the Meridian, and it will fall out directly to bee in the Zenith of that Elevation upon this ground, That the Elevation is alwaies equal to the Latitude; then faÅ¿ten the Quadrant of Altitude upon the Zenith, and turn it about till it fall upon the other Place, and the End of the Quadrant will point out the Situation upon the Horizon. Let the Places bee Oxford and the Hill in Tenariff, Å¿et the Globe to the Elevation of Oxford, that is 51 Degrees of Elevation above the Horizon, then bring Oxford to the Meridian, and it falleth under 51 Degrees of Latitude from the Equator, therefore it is found in it's own Vertical Point 90 Degrees equidiÅ¿tantly removed from the Horizon: FaÅ¿ten there the Quadrant, and move about the Plate till it fall upon the Hill in Tenariff, and the end of the Quadrant where it toucheth
the Horizon will Å¿hew that the Hill in Tenariff beareth from Oxford South South-WeÅ¿t: and if you multiplie the the Degrees of the Quadrant intercepted betwixt the two Places by 60, you have the DiÅ¿tance in Miles, which was promiÅ¿ed before.

If you finde, as you needs muÅ¿t, that the Proportion of Miles upon the Globe doth not alwaies anÅ¿wer to that which wee reckon upon in the Earth, you are deÅ¿ired not to think much; for when it is promiÅ¿ed that 60 of our Miles Å¿hall run out a Degree of a Great Circle above, it is intended upon this SuppoÅ¿ition, as if the Earth wee tread upon were preciÅ¿ely round as the Globe it Å¿elf is, and not interrupted with Rivers, Hills, Vallies, &c. which though they bear no proportion otherwiÅ¿e, yet becauÅ¿ it cometh to paÅ¿s by this that wee cannot Å¿et our courÅ¿ in a Streight Line upon the Earth as the DemonÅ¿tration is forced to preÅ¿uppoÅ¿e, wee muÅ¿t bee contented if Å¿om difference fall out.

The more unhappie Difference will bee found in the Longitudes themÅ¿elvs. The Difference of Longitude betwixt Rome and Norenberg (as M. Gellibrand hath already made the ObÅ¿ervation) is according to Kepler, but 4 Minutes of Time: Lansbergh reckoneth it at 10 Degrees, Mercator at 12, Stadius at 18, Longomontanus at 16, Stoffler at 18, Maginus at 26, Werner at 32, Origan at 33, Appian at 34, Regiomontanus at 36: with diÅ¿couragement enough it may bee noted, for the Places are verie eminent, and of a near DiÅ¿tance: the Men profeÅ¿Å¿ed able, and for the moÅ¿t part reckoning from the Å¿ame Great Meridian; and yet the leÅ¿s to bee wondred at, if wee conÅ¿ider how much in this caÅ¿e muÅ¿t bee taken upon truÅ¿t, even by theÅ¿e Men themÅ¿elvs. Wee muÅ¿t not think they all Å¿pake this of their own Knowledg, for it is certain the thing might have been, and is don, though not without anie at all, yet without anie conÅ¿iderable diÅ¿agreement. I Å¿aie the Longitudes for a very great part, are exactly enough agreed on. The perfection is not one Man's, nor one Ages Work, and muÅ¿t bee waited for. It muÅ¿t not Å¿eem Å¿trange if I tell you that you may diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h the more certain from the doubtful by their dÅ¿convenience, for
where you finde them to agree, you have cauÅ¿ to Å¿uÅ¿pect (for the moÅ¿t part) that they have lien long upon the Lees of Time, not as yet enquired into. But if you finde them to diÅ¿agree, you may conclude that they have been brought to a new Examination. And of theÅ¿e, you are to take the lateÅ¿t, and from Å¿uch (if it may bee) as have don it by their own ObÅ¿ervation, as out of the Tables of Tycho before others. The difference of Longitude by Tycho's Tables betwixt Rome and Norenberg is under 4 Degrees, which cometh neareÅ¿t to Kepler, who alÅ¿o took it himÅ¿elf from two Å¿everal obÅ¿ervations of the Moon. There will Å¿till Å¿eem to bee Å¿om want of Å¿atisfaction, but it is Å¿ufficient for anie man to know in this as much as anie other man doth.

If you would convert the Degrees of Longitude into Hours (for this alÅ¿o may bee don as well into Miles) you are to allow 15 Degrees to one Hour, upon the ReaÅ¿ons taught before; and that which will bee gained by this is to know, by how much Å¿ooner or later the Sun RiÅ¿eth, or Setteth to one Place then to another. As the Difference of Longitude betwixt Oxford and Charlton is 79 Degrees, 30 Minutes: that is, 5 Hours, 18 Minutes: and becauÅ¿ Charlton lieth WeÅ¿t from London, the Sun RiÅ¿eth Å¿o much Å¿ooner here then there.

div.head: To finde out the Å¿everal PoÅ¿itions of Sphere, Clime, Parallel, &c.
div.p: THe Latitude and Longitude of a Place once reÅ¿olved upon, the other Accidents of Sphere will follow of themÅ¿elvs: the PoÅ¿ition of Sphere you cannot miÅ¿s of, for if the Place you trie for have no Latitude at all, you know alreadie that it muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿itie lie under the Line it Å¿elf, and therefore in a right PoÅ¿ition. If it have leÅ¿s, or more the PoÅ¿ition is oblique. If it have as much as it can have, that is the Whole Quadrant, or 90 Degrees, the PoÅ¿ition is Parallel; the reaÅ¿ons were told before, and may evidently bee diÅ¿cerned upon the Globe.

For the Climes and Parallels, and conÅ¿equently the length of the longeÅ¿t Daie, The fore-knowledg of the Latitude leadeth you directly, in caÅ¿e the Climes bee Å¿et down upon the BraÅ¿s Meridian, or in anie void part of the Globe, otherwiÅ¿e it is but entring the Table of Climes and Parallels proportioned to everie Degree of Latitude, and you have your deÅ¿ire. And as by the Latitude you may finde out the Clime, Å¿o if it happen that you knew the Clime before, as it may in the reading of the EÅ¿tats du Monde, or the like DeÅ¿cribers, you may by the Clime finde out the Latitude; And you cannot know either of theÅ¿e, but you muÅ¿t needs know the Zone: And if you know that, you can as eaÅ¿ily conclude upon the Distinction of Shadows, for you knew before that the Inhabitants of the Mid Zone are alwaies AÅ¿cii or AmphiÅ¿cii; thoÅ¿e of the two Extreme PeriÅ¿cii; thoÅ¿e of the two Temperate or Intermedious, HeteroÅ¿cii. To finde out the other DiÅ¿tinction of Habitation you may do thus: Let Oxford bee the Place; bring it to the Meridian, where you finde it to bee 51 Degrees lifted up above the Equator; account Å¿o manie Degrees of Southern Latitude below the Equator, and you meet with the Antaeci (if anie bee) in the Terra AuÅ¿tralis incognita; remove Oxford from the Meridian 180 Degrees, and you Å¿hall finde your Periaeci under the Meridian where Oxford was before, about the Bay of S. MichaÃ«l in the Kingdom of Quivira, and your Antipodes in the place where their Antaeci Å¿tood before, but they are not, for the Place is covered over with Water.

There yet remaineth one waie of DeÅ¿cription, but out of Curious Art, and of no great InÅ¿truction, yet becauÅ¿ it is made uÅ¿e of by Å¿om Geographers, and not left out by M. Camden himÅ¿elf in his Britannia, I may tell what it meaneth.

div.head: Of AÅ¿trological Geographie, and to tell under what Sign, or Planet, a Region, or Citie is Å¿ubjected.
div.p:
THe WiÅ¿dom of the Antients (it was called Å¿o) held an Opinion that not our Å¿elvs onely, the Little Worlds, but the Great Globe of the EARTH alÅ¿o is particularly reigned over by the Dominion of the 12 Signs, and Influence of the 7 Planets; upon which Principle (as wee receiv it by Ptolomie's Tradition) they divided this Globe into 4 Quadrants by the InterÅ¿ection of the Equator with the Great Meridian paÅ¿Å¿ing by the Canaries. Every of theÅ¿e Quadrants they again divided into 4 Trigons, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting each of them of 3 Signs of the Zodiack, not orderly, but Å¿o as that everie Trigon night bee made up of one Fixt Sign, one Moveable, and the third Common, as they diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h. The firÅ¿t Quadrant was reckoned from the Vernal by the Pole to the Autumnal InterÅ¿ection, and was called the Quadrant of the Habitable World: for every one of the other three was to that Time a Terra incognita. The firÅ¿t Trigon of this Quadrant falleth to the Dominion of Aries, Leo, and Sagittarius. The Second to Taurus, Virgo, and Capricornus, and to the Influence of Å¿uch Planets as are connatural to Å¿uch Signs. So Britain, France, Germanie, &c. fall to the Å¿hare of Aries and his Planet Mars. Italie, Sicilie, &c. to Leo: Norwaie, Bavaria, &c. to Scorpio; and Å¿o forwards, concluding all, and every Part and Province of the Globe under one, or other of the Twelv. But this emptie Speculation Å¿topped not here, but would make us believ too, that not Whole Countries onely, but everie Citie, CaÅ¿tle, Village, nay, not a private HouÅ¿, or a Ship that ride's upon the OceÃ¤n but is thus diÅ¿tinctly governed by their Planets. They do it upon this ground: ThoÅ¿e men allow as earneÅ¿t a livelihood to the Beam in the Timber, and Stone in the Wall as to themÅ¿elvs. And when the firÅ¿t Stone of a Building is laid, a Citie or
HouÅ¿ is Å¿aid to bee born, and as Formal a Figure erected of that, as of the Owner's Nativitie.

The Emperor ConÅ¿tantine (though you would not think it) at the Building of his new Rome commanded Valens, (a named AÅ¿trologer of that Time) to Calculate the Nativitie, and make Judgment of the Life and Duration of that Imperial Citie. The AÅ¿Å¿cendent was Cancer, and the AÅ¿trologer Å¿aid that the Empire Å¿hould Å¿tand 696 years, and (whether hee knew Å¿o much or not) hee Å¿aid true; the Citie lived longer indeed, but all the reÅ¿t was but labor and Å¿orrow. And for a more private ManÅ¿ion, there is yet now to bee Å¿een the Nativitie of the Warden's Lodgings of Merton College in one of the Windows; the HoroÅ¿cope the Å¿ame with that of ConÅ¿tantinople; now look what Sign of the twelv Å¿hall bee found to riÅ¿e up in the HoroÅ¿cope or Angle of the EaÅ¿t, that is the Sign-Regent of that HouÅ¿, or Citie. No more but Å¿o, Let the two Places into whoÅ¿e DiÅ¿tance you enquire bee London and Paris, finde the Longitude and Latitude of both the Places in the PlaniÅ¿phere; then again finde the Å¿ame Longitude and Latitude upon the Globe, then Å¿et one foot of your CompaÅ¿s upon the Place where London, and the other foot where Paris Å¿hould bee upon the Globe, and bring your CompaÅ¿s with that DiÅ¿tance to the Equator: And the Degrees intercepted, multiplied into Miles by 60, Å¿hew the DiÅ¿tance. This is as much as to tell us, that in meaÅ¿uring the DiÅ¿tances of Places there is no great truÅ¿t to bee had to any PlaniÅ¿pherical Projection whatÅ¿oever: for though that by the Section of the Equator bee nearer to the Sphere then this by the Section of the Meridian, yet they are both equally engaged in this Imperfection that they cannot Å¿atisfie for the gibboÅ¿itie of the Globe.

div.head: The DeÅ¿cription and UÅ¿e of Particular Charts.
div.p: PArticular Maps are but Limbs of the Globe, and therefore though they are drawn aÅ¿under, yet it is Å¿till to bee don with that proportion, as a remembring Eie may Å¿uddenly acknowledg, and join them to the whole Bodie.

They are moÅ¿t commonly deÅ¿cribed upon a Parallelogramme, but their relation to the Bodie it Å¿elf is not to bee judged by this. It is not don to that end, but that beeing but Parts and Members Å¿evered from the Whole, they yet might make Å¿hew of as great an appearance of Integritie as could bee allowed.
Their Place in their Bodie is to bee eÅ¿teemed from their proper Lineaments, drawn within the Square, that is, Å¿uch Portions of Meridians and Parallels as they conÅ¿iÅ¿ted of in the Globe it Å¿elf.
Briefly to the ConÅ¿titution of a particular Chart, TheÅ¿e Moments eÅ¿pecially make up the Projection, the Graduation, The Reference to the great Meridian, the Scale, and the CompaÅ¿s.

Projection.The Projection is moÅ¿t commonly (as I Å¿aid) upon a Parallelogramme, Å¿omtimes inÅ¿cribed with an Oval, as the Map of Flanders, and Germane BaÅ¿Å¿e in Ortelius; or upon a Circle, as that of the North Pole in Mercator's Atlas: And becauÅ¿ no Region is exactly Å¿quare or round, Å¿o much of the bordering Territories are uÅ¿ually thruÅ¿t in, as may not onely declare the Bounds, but fill up the Square too.

The Projection is mainly concerned in the fore-knowledg of the Longitude and Latitude of the Countrie: And the Latitude is to bee expreÅ¿Å¿ed by Parallels from North to South, as the Longitude by Meridians from WeÅ¿t to EaÅ¿t, each of them at 10 Degrees diÅ¿tance, or the Meridians at 15, as the Geographer Å¿hall pleaÅ¿, and may bee drawn either by Circle, as the Maps of AÅ¿ia and America in Ortelius his Theatrum;
or by right Line, and that either extended, as in the Map of Africa there, or onely begun upon the Parallelogramme, as in the Map of Europe; and then the two extreme Parallels may bee the North and South Å¿ides of the Parallelogramme: but if they bee right Lines, they are not (that is, the Meridians are not) to bee drawn direct or parallel, but inclining and concurring to confeÅ¿s the Nature of the Whole, whereof they are Å¿uch parts, and the named Parallels are more notably to bee diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿ht then the reÅ¿t, if they have place in the Map, as in that of Africa you have the Equator, and both the Tropicks either graduated, as the Equator, or drawn double at leaÅ¿t, as the Tropicks, &c.

For the Graduation. Graduation. The Degrees of Longitude are moÅ¿t commonly divided upon the North and South Å¿ides of the Parallelogramme. The Degrees of Latitude upon the EaÅ¿t and WeÅ¿t Å¿ides, or otherwiÅ¿e upon the moÅ¿t EaÅ¿tern and WeÅ¿tern Meridian of the Map within the Square, as in the DeÅ¿criptions of Ptolemie continually; or if the Projection bee upon a Circle, as that of the North Pole in the Atlas, the Degrees of Longitude are Å¿et upon the uttermoÅ¿t Parallel, and thoÅ¿e of Latitude upon a portion of the Great Meridian, anÅ¿werable to the Semidiameter of that Latitude. And the Climes maie bee Å¿et down to the Degrees of Latitude, as in the DeÅ¿cription of Portugal by Vernandus Alvarus. But it hath Å¿eemed good to Å¿om Geographers, nay, even to Ortelius himÅ¿elf in theÅ¿e particular DeÅ¿criptions for the moÅ¿t part to make no Graduation or Projection at all; but to put the matter off to a Scale of Miles, and leav the reÅ¿t to bee beleev'd. Whether this or Mercator's waie in the Atlas were more Artificial, I will not judg in the cauÅ¿ of the King of Spain's Geographer.

For the firÅ¿t Meridian, Reference to the great Meridian. It is a fault you will more generally finde, that there is verie Å¿eldom any expreÅ¿Å¿ion of that Reference, Å¿o that though there bee Graduation, and the Longitude Å¿et before your eies, yet you will finde your Å¿elf uncertain, unleÅ¿s it bee told you before, that the Longitudes in Mr Camdem, Speed, Nordon, and the late EngliÅ¿h DeÅ¿cribers
generally are taken from Mercator's FirÅ¿t Meridian, by S. Michael in the Azores, though Å¿om of them indeed (and not M. Camdem onely, but Å¿uch too as made it their buÅ¿ineÅ¿s to do otherwiÅ¿e) have propoÅ¿ed the Matter in effect to bee don by the Canaries as the Autor of the Brief Introduction to Geographie, (if I underÅ¿tand him) in theÅ¿e words.

Æ²pon the Globe there are manie (Meridians) drawn, all which paÅ¿s through the Poles, and go North and South; but there is one more remarkable than the reÅ¿t drawn broad with Å¿mall DiviÅ¿ions, which runneth thorough the Canarie-IÅ¿lands or Azores, WeÅ¿tward of Spain, which is counted the firÅ¿t Meridian in regard of reckoning and meaÅ¿uring of DiÅ¿tances of places one from another; for otherwiÅ¿e there if neither firÅ¿t nor laÅ¿t in the round Earth: But Å¿om place muÅ¿t bee appointed where to begin the Account: And thoÅ¿e IÅ¿lands have been thought fitteÅ¿t, becauÅ¿ no part of the World that laie WeÅ¿tward was known to the Antients further than that: and as they began to reckon, there wee follow them.

But as concerning Mercator himÅ¿elf you have more to look to. Mercator's conÅ¿tant Meridian was that by S. MichaÃ«l, and Å¿o you will finde it in the Atlas, Å¿et out by Rumuldus. But in that of Hondius Edition lately tranÅ¿lated into EngliÅ¿h, you will finde it otherwiÅ¿e, though you Å¿hall Å¿ee too in what a fair waie you are to bee deceived of this alÅ¿o.

In the DeÅ¿cription of IÅ¿land, pag. 33. The Book Å¿aith, It is Å¿ituated not under the firÅ¿t Meridian, as one hath noted, but in the eighth Degree from thence. To which the Margin (but not knowing what) Å¿aith,

That this firÅ¿t Meridian is a great Circle rounding the Earth from Pole to Pole, and paÅ¿Å¿ing thorough the IÅ¿lands called Azores, and namely the IÅ¿le of S. MichaÃ«l, as the Å¿ame Noter to pag. 10.
Hee might think hee went upon a ground good enough; for in the Å¿eventh Chapter of the Introduction, Mercator himÅ¿elf, Å¿aith thus:

Ptolomie hath placed the firÅ¿t Meridian in the Fortunate IÅ¿les; which at this daie are called the Canaries. Since, the SpaniÅ¿h Pilots
have placed it in the IÅ¿le of GoÅ¿s-hauks, which in their Language are called AÅ¿Å¿ores, and Å¿om of them placed it in the middle of Spain, &c.

Now wee muÅ¿t hold (Å¿aith hee) that the Longitude is a certain Å¿pace or interval of the Equator cloÅ¿ed between Meridians, the one from the IÅ¿les called Azores, from whence it taketh the begining; the other, from that Place or Region, whereof wee would know the DiÅ¿tance.

And yet for all this the Longitudes in that Book are accounted from the Canaries, as you may Å¿ee in the EaÅ¿t HemiÅ¿phere, and in the general DeÅ¿cription of Africa. The Editioner Hondius would have it Å¿o, and (which is marvel the Marginal Noter could chuÅ¿e but know) hee himÅ¿elf in the verie Begining maketh this ProfeÅ¿Å¿ion of it;

Ptolomie, Å¿aith hee, and wee in this Book do make the Longitude to bee a Å¿egment of the Equator comprehended betwixt the Meridian of the place, and the Meridian of the Fortunate IÅ¿lands, for from theÅ¿e IÅ¿lands the Begining of Longitude is taken, &c.
Having Å¿aved you this Labor in Mercator, you may now bee told what is to bee don with Ortelius.

For his own DeÅ¿criptions hee alwaies taketh to Ptolomie's Meridian by the Canaries, as you may Å¿ee in his Æ²niverÅ¿al Face of the World, and in the General DeÅ¿cription of Africa, to the DeÅ¿cription of HiÅ¿paniola, Cuba, Culiacan, &c. hee giveth this Admonition.

div.p:
The like Note hee affixeth to the DeÅ¿cription of New-Spain: his meaning in both is, to let the Reader know that the DeÅ¿criber (who ever hee was) did not in theÅ¿e Maps account the Degrees of Longitude, as Ptolomie, from WeÅ¿t to EaÅ¿t, and from the Fortunate IÅ¿les; but from EaÅ¿t to WeÅ¿t, and from the Meridian of Toledo HiÅ¿paniae Æ²mbilico; which is the meaning of Mercator, when hee Å¿aith, That Å¿om of the SpaniÅ¿h Pilots placed the Great Meridian in the middle of
Spain. And if you look upon the Longitude in the North and South Å¿ides of the Parallelogram, you Å¿hall Å¿ee the Degrees reckoned backwards contrarie to the received manner of Graduation. It is no verie hard matter to reduce theÅ¿e Longitudes to the ordinarie waie, but rather then Å¿o, you may have recourÅ¿ to the Later DeÅ¿cription of America, by Leat and others.

For the Scale, in particular Maps extending to a conÅ¿iderable portion of Longitude and Latitude, it dependeth for the ground upon the Degrees of the Great Circle, and the Proportion of Miles in Å¿everal Countries to anie Å¿uch Degree. But in LeÅ¿Å¿er DeÅ¿criptions it hath more to do with the known diÅ¿tance of anie two, or more places experimentally found, or taken upon truÅ¿t of Common Reputation.

Here it is not to bee thought that the Longitudes and Latitudes of all Places in a particular Chart need to bee taken, but of the Principal onely, the reÅ¿t to bee reduced by the Radius, the Angle of PoÅ¿ition, and the like; and much alÅ¿o in this matter uÅ¿eth to bee given to the Common Supputation; all which, the laÅ¿t eÅ¿pecially are the CauÅ¿Å¿es why the Maps agree no better, for of all other the Account of the Common People is moÅ¿t uncertain.

The French CoÅ¿mographer of Amiens before named, when hee took upon him to finde out how manie of their Leagues anÅ¿wered to a Degree, took his Journie from Paris as directly under the Meridian as hee might, till hee rode 25 Leagues according to the Account of the Inhabitants of the Place. Now as the Miles of Å¿everal Countries do verie much differ, Å¿o thoÅ¿e of the Å¿ame do not verie much agree: and therefore the Scales are commonly written upon with Magna, Mediocria, Parva, to Å¿hew the Difference.

Of Common EngliÅ¿h and Italian Miles 60 (as you know already) anÅ¿wer to a Degree of a Great Circle: 68 Å¿aith Fernelius: it ought to bee 63 and Å¿omwhat more by the Semidiameter of the Earth, as it was taken by Mr Edward Wright near Plimmouth-Sound; dut 60 is moÅ¿t commonly beleeved and is the proportion (which in a verie Å¿mall matter) received by Ptolomie himÅ¿elf from Marinus the Tyrian with this approbation: Ptolom. In Å¿om Maps you Å¿hall finde the Miles thus hiddenly Å¿et down, as in that of Artois in Ortelius and elÅ¿where. And the meaning Å¿till is, that you Å¿hould meaÅ¿ure the Milliaria magna upon the LowermoÅ¿t Line, the Parva upon the uppermoÅ¿t, and the Mediocria upon the MiddlemoÅ¿t.

In Å¿om other Maps, as in that of WeÅ¿tphalia in the Å¿ame Autor, you will finde the Scale written upon with Milliaria magna, mediocria, & Horae itineris. Therefore one Hour-Mile of a Journie upon HorÅ¿, anÅ¿wereth to four EngliÅ¿h Miles: And yet it is Å¿et down before the Atlas that the proportion of Itinerarie Hours to a Degree is 20: They cannot both bee true, 'tis enough to Å¿hew how uncertain this waie of meaÅ¿uring needs muÅ¿t bee.

For the UÅ¿e of the Scale it is but Å¿etting one foot of your CompaÅ¿s in the little Circles of the places and bringing the CompaÅ¿s kept at that DiÅ¿tance to the Scale, and you have the number of great or middle Miles, according as the Inhabitants of thoÅ¿e places are known to reckon.

div.head: Example of all this in the DeÅ¿cription of Saxton's Map of England and Wales.
div.p: ALl this may bee exemplified in Å¿om one Particular Chart. The example uÅ¿eth to bee given in the DeÅ¿cription of France, but might more properly bee made upon a Map of our own Countrie. There bee Å¿everal of theÅ¿e as that of Humfrey Llyid, that of Wortnel, Mr Speed's DeÅ¿criptions and others; but wee chuÅ¿e that of Saxton, a man recommended unto us by Mr Camden himÅ¿elf in the Preface to his Britannia.

Nonnulli erunt fortaÅ¿Å¿e qui Tabulas chorographicas hÃ®c exÅ¿pectent quas lenocinante picturÃ¢ oculis eÅ¿Å¿e jucundiores, & in his Geographicis Å¿tudiis plurimÃ¹m intereÅ¿Å¿e fateor; maximÃ¨ Å¿i mutis Tabulis literarum etiam lumen accedat. Hoc tamen praeÅ¿tare facultatis non eÅ¿t noÅ¿trae; & Angliam accuratiÅ¿Å¿imÃ¨ in Tabulis Å¿eorÅ¿im ornatiÅ¿Å¿imus Vir Thomas Seckfordus Regiae MajeÅ¿tati Ã Å¿upplicum Libellis, Å¿uis impenÅ¿is, & ChriÅ¿tophori Saxtoni optimi Chorographi operÃ¢, magnÃ¢ cum laude deÅ¿cripÅ¿it.

Saxton drew up Typographical DeÅ¿criptions of this Kingdom by the Shires and Counties into a Å¿et Volume of Tables; but whatÅ¿oever can bee Å¿everally Å¿aid of them may better bee Å¿poken all at once upon his great Chorographical Map of the Whole. A DeÅ¿cription, which if it exceed not (as I think it doth) yet may compare with anie particular Table made or to bee made of anie Countrie whatÅ¿oever.

The DeÅ¿cription is of England onely and Wales, that it might bee the more exact and uÅ¿eful, which exÅ¿pectation is Å¿o accurately anÅ¿wered that the Å¿malleÅ¿t Village may bee turn'd to there; Henxey or Botlie, as well as Oxford.

It is deÅ¿crib'd upon a Parallelogram: the North and South Å¿ides are Parallels of Latitude divided into Degrees of Longitude. The EaÅ¿t and WeÅ¿t Å¿ides Å¿tand for Meridians, and
are divided into Degres of Latitude, and everie Degree Å¿ubdivided into 60 Parts, but Å¿o, that a Degree of Longitude anÅ¿wereth but to Å¿o manie parts of a Degree of Latitude, as it ought in that Parallel. The Parallels as the Meridians are Å¿et down at one Degrees diÅ¿tance: the Parallels are Parallels indeed; the Meridians are Streight Lines, but more and more concurring from South to North, as is required from the nature of the Sphere.

The Latitude of the Countries is from 50 Degrees 8 Minutes to 55 and 50 Minutes. The Longitude from 17 to 25 Degrees and 9 Minutes: And 'tis reckoned from St MichaÃ«l and St Maries in the Azores, as the Geographer himÅ¿elf there expreÅ¿Å¿eth: Longitudinis gradus ab eo Meridiano capiunt initium qui per Divae Mariae InÅ¿ulam tranÅ¿it, quae omnium Azorearum maximÃ¨ ad Orientem vergit.

The Middle Parallel of the Countrie it Å¿elf is Å¿omwhat of a LeÅ¿Å¿er Latitude, and may bee imagined to paÅ¿s a not much beÅ¿ides Tidburie CaÅ¿tle in StaffordÅ¿hire, as Mr Norden thought. The Scale of Miles is anÅ¿werable to one Degree of Latitude, and is alÅ¿o divided, as they, into 60 Parts. In finding out the Longitude, or Latitude of anie Citie or Town in the Map, the manner is the Å¿ame as in anie other, for the Longitude is to bee reckoned in the North and South Å¿ides, the Latitude in the EaÅ¿t and WeÅ¿t Å¿ides of the Parallelogram.

But the Situation and DiÅ¿tance of the Places in a particular
Chart are moÅ¿t of moment, the Situations are plain. The DiÅ¿tances in this Map, where I could prove them experimentally, for the moÅ¿t part were found true. div.head: Of Topographical Maps, and for an Example the DeÅ¿cription of MiddleÅ¿ex by Mr Norden.
div.p: Geograph. lib. 1. cap. 1. NOw that you may not bee miÅ¿taken in Terms, the DeÅ¿cription of the Whole whether by Parallelogramme, or PlaniÅ¿phere is moÅ¿t rightfully called Geographie in Plano.
Geographiae proprium eÅ¿t (Å¿aith Ptolemie) unam & continuam terram cognitam oÅ¿tendere quemadmodum Å¿e habeat naturÃ¢ & poÅ¿itione.
The DeÅ¿cription of anie verie great part of the Earth, as France, England, or the like, is moÅ¿t properly called Chorographie.

Ptolomie himÅ¿elf goeth no further in diÅ¿tinctions; for having Å¿aid, That Geographie is an imitation of the Picture of the Earth, with intimation of reference to the drawing of the leÅ¿Å¿er Worlds; hee addeth, PorrÃ² finis Chorographicus connexione particulari continetur, veluti Å¿i quis aurem tantÃ¹m aut oculum imitetur. And indeed the Tables of Ptolomie needed no other Difference in terms. But the late Geographers finding it fitteÅ¿t of all to make DeÅ¿criptions of Å¿mall Parcels of the Earth, as Shires and Counties to us, the Circles of the Empire in CompariÅ¿on to the GreatneÅ¿s of that, and the like; They have fallen upon a third member of this DiviÅ¿ion, calling theÅ¿e kinde of DeÅ¿criptions Topographie, though Ptolomie did minutiÅ¿Å¿imas proprietates Chorographiae attribuere. And the word it Å¿elf will not allow of anie verie great DiÅ¿tinction from the other, if it had not been gained upon by UÅ¿e.

Now as there is no Chorographical Map or DeÅ¿cription of the whole Region, or Countrie of this Kingdom can bee more exactly according to Art, or according to InduÅ¿trie more particularly performed than that of Saxton, Å¿o for the DeÅ¿criptions of the Shires or Counties thereof (which muÅ¿t then bee called their Topographie) No man whatÅ¿oever
hath lighted upon a more exact and preÅ¿ent waie of Delineation then the Industrious Norden.

The intent of this Man was to make an abÅ¿olute DeÅ¿cription of the Whole, and everie part of this Kingdom of Great Britain: It pleaÅ¿ed him to call this purpoÅ¿e, Speculum Britanniae. The firÅ¿t Part whereof (which is onely completed) affordeth us a general DeÅ¿cription of the Kingdom, with a particular DeÅ¿cription and Topographical Table of MiddleÅ¿ex. The Table is projected upon a Parallelogramme, the Å¿ides whereof are divided into Miles, Å¿o that though the Å¿ides look like Meridians and Parallels; yet they are not Å¿o, but a meer Scale, from which therefore are drawn croÅ¿s the Table Å¿mall black equidiÅ¿tant lines, looking alÅ¿o like to Parallels and Meridians, but Å¿erving onely for the readier taking of the DiÅ¿tances, the DiviÅ¿ions of theÅ¿e Lines from EaÅ¿t to WeÅ¿t Å¿tanding for two, from North to South for four Miles. The Letters upon the EaÅ¿t and WeÅ¿t Å¿ide, and figures upon the North and South Å¿ide, Å¿erv for the finding out any place by the Direction of the Alphabet: For Example, The Alphabet, Å¿aith Brentford. H. 12. See H in the EaÅ¿t or WeÅ¿t Å¿ide, 12 upon the North or South Å¿ide, and then by the Square made by the black Lines you fall upon the Place. The Figures here and there about, which in the Parallelogramme, 2, 3, 4, 5, and to 11 Note out the Principal High-Waies from London thorough MiddleÅ¿ex, as number the 4 by Northolt is to Å¿hew the waie to Æ²xbridg, and Å¿o to Oxford, &c. This is told you in the Speculum, fol. 49. a. And theÅ¿e High-Waies are diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed out by the Lines of Points; for that of One is to define out the Bounds of the Shire, as you may Å¿ee upon the WeÅ¿t Å¿ide it paÅ¿Å¿eth by the River Colne to Shyreditch, &c. The Capital Letters A, B, C, &c. are to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h the Hundreds of the Countie, as the Speculum Å¿aith, fol. 13. A.
